headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, and thank you standing by. Welcome to Western Digital's Financial Results for the Second Quarter of Fiscal Year 2016. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this call is being recorded. Now, I'll turn the call over to Mr. Bob Blair. You ma
componenttext: Good afternoon, and thank you standing by. Welcome to Western Digital's Financial Results for the Second Quarter of Fiscal Year 2016. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this call is being recorded. Now, I'll turn the call over to Mr. Bob Blair. You may begin.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and good afternoon. This conference call contains forward-looking statements within the meaning of the federal securities laws. Such forward-looking statements are based upon management's current expectations and include known and unknown risks
componenttext:
Thank you, and good afternoon. This conference call contains forward-looking statements within the meaning of the federal securities laws. Such forward-looking statements are based upon management's current expectations and include known and unknown risks, uncertainties and other factors, many of which Western Digital is unable to predict or control, that may cause our actual results, performance or game plans to differ materially from those expressed or implied by such forward-looking statements. This conference call does not constitute an offer to purchase or the solicitation of an offer to sell any securities or a solicitation of any vote or approval in connection with the pending merger with SanDisk. Western Digital filed a Form S-4 registration statement with the SEC that includes proxy statements of SanDisk and Western Digital and a prospectus of Western Digital regarding the merger. After the joint proxy statement prospectus is declared effective, Western Digital and SanDisk will mail the definitive joint proxy statement prospectus to the respective shareholders. Investors and shareholders should read the joint proxy statements and prospectus carefully when it becomes available because it contains important information about the merger. In addition, Western Digital, SanDisk and their respective directors, executive officers and certain other members of management and employees may be soliciting proxies from their respective shareholders in favor of the proposed transaction. You can find information about Western Digital directors and executive officers in Western Digital's most recent proxy statement, and about SanDisk's directors and executive officers in SanDisk's most recent proxy statement. You may obtain a copy of these documents with the SEC's website or in the Western Digital's and SanDisk's websites. 
Further references will be made during this call to non-GAAP financial measures. Reconciliations of the difference -- differences between the non-GAAP measures we provide during this call to the comparable GAAP financial measures are included in the quarterly fact sheet posted in the Investor Relations section of our websites. 
I also want to highlight that the information provided during this call today regarding the savings we realized as a result of the integration of our WD and HGST subsidiaries and the expected costs to achieve in such savings are included in the quarterly fact sheet posted in the Investor Relations section of our website. 
[Operator Instructions] 
I also want to note that copies of remarks of today's call will be available on the Investors section some time later after this call. 
And now, I'd like to turn the call over to Steve Milligan, Chief Executive Officer.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us. With me today are Mike Cordano, our President and Chief Operating Officer; and Olivier Leonetti, our Chief Financial Officer. After my opening remarks, Olivier will give additional commentary on our December
componenttext:
Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us. 
With me today are Mike Cordano, our President and Chief Operating Officer; and Olivier Leonetti, our Chief Financial Officer. After my opening remarks, Olivier will give additional commentary on our December quarter performance and our outlook for the March quarter. He will also provide an update on the expected integration savings resulting from the lift of almost all of the restrictions MOFCOM have placed on our business. 
We continue to execute well as we manage our business within an increasingly challenging global economic environment. We reported revenue of $3.3 billion, non-GAAP gross margin of 28.5% and non-GAAP diluted earnings per share of $1.60. We also had strong free cash flow performance of $449 million and our storage shipments for the December quarter grew to 69.1 exabytes. The HDD TAM in the December quarter came in somewhat below our expectations. The gaming sector was weaker and enterprise volumes were a bit lighter than expected. We anticipate weak demand in the March quarter, resulting in a hard drive TAM of approximately 100 million units. The main factors behind this forecast are the expected combination of seasonal and secular trends, as well as increased caution among customers and end markets relative to challenging global economic conditions. Being able to integrate our HGST and WD subsidiaries and transform into one company affords us the opportunity to optimize our business model for both the near and long-term. We are taking a number of important steps in this context. We are reducing our cost base through a series of planned actions, including the elimination of redundancy in functions, products and facilities. Olivier will provide additional detail in the magnitude and timing of the integration related savings, but let me cite a few examples. 
Last week, we announced the closure of our head waiver manufacturing facility in Ottawa, Japan, one of our three head wafers facilities. We are streamlining our product road map by focusing our efforts to eliminate redundancy and optimize the products we offer, resulting in the elimination of a minimum of 6 programs. And we recently set our new leadership team with a plan to complete our new companywide organizational structure in the June quarter. We believe this aggressive approach to reduce our cost structure will maintain and extend our cost leadership in the hard drive industry. 
Turning to the longer-term. We remain focused on transforming Western Digital into one of the world's leading companies in the large, rapidly changing and high-growth storage industry. We continue to believe in the unabated growth in the creation of data, in the amount of data being stored and in our ability to create long-term value for our customers and shareholders. We continue to diversify our revenue base in the higher growth areas, aligned with cloud storage and the third platform of computing. This includes building on our track record of innovation in Capacity Enterprise, most recently, with our leadership in helium sealed drives. Our helium drives shipments totaled a record 1.5 million in the December quarter, including initial shipments of our 10-terabyte drive, our third-generation helium drive. First shipped by Western Digital in 2013, we are pleased with the success and wider adoption of helium technology and enterprise IT as it marks the shift for hard drive makers to deliver value added storage solutions to customers based on a value proposition of better total cost of ownership. 
Our Enterprise SSD revenue grew to $270 million in the December quarter. While we continue to believe Enterprise SSD will be one of our main growth drivers, we expect to see a pause in our growth in the March quarter, given typical seasonal factors in enterprise IT spending and as we proceed through a SAS product transition. And we continue to see good traction in our Active Archive systems business, with several wins in Tier 2 cloud infrastructure, backup and archive applications and other vertical markets. 
Regarding the SanDisk acquisition. We are pleased with the progress we're making in obtaining required regulatory approvals. It has always been our goal to close the acquisition as soon as possible and as noted in our Form 8-K filing earlier this month, we have competed the FTC review in the U.S. I would also note that the FTC completed its review without issuing a second request, which we see as confirmation of our view that this transaction is pro competitive. We also received recent approvals from antitrust agencies in Singapore and Japan. Based on our work with other agencies around the world, we currently anticipate that the acquisition will close in the June quarter. 
I would like to emphasize the importance of the acquisition of SanDisk to our overall strategic plan. Once we close the acquisition, we will have the broadest set of products to offer our customers, a deep technology base across nonvolatile memory and rotating magnetic media and an expanded addressable market. 
On the Unisplendour investment, we and Unisplendour continue to work with [indiscernible] as they review the proposed investment in Western Digital. [indiscernible] has not yet reached a decision on whether the investment is a covered transaction. We continue to believe that we have structured this investment carefully in order to avoid that result. Given [indiscernible] heavy caseload towards the end of last year, we asked to withdraw and refile our notice in order to provide additional time for us to engage with them on our case. Sifius agreed to our request and we refiled in January. We know and expect a decision from Sifius some time in February. Our strategic joint venture with Unisplendour to sell our storage systems in Japan is proceeding as planned. We successfully negotiated its terms, including operational and governance plans in late 2015. And with those complete, we are now in the process of satisfying certain closing conditions while simultaneously recruiting and staffing the JV. 
I'm very excited about the company's future and our ability to create long-term value for our customers, shareholders and employees. 
Olivier will now provide his commentary before we take your questions.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Steve. Our revenue for the December quarter was $3.3 billion. We shipped a total of 49.7 million hard drives at an average selling price of $61. Our non-GAAP gross margin was 28.5% and operating expenses totaled $542 million. Non-GAAP tax exp
componenttext:
Thank you, Steve. 
Our revenue for the December quarter was $3.3 billion. We shipped a total of 49.7 million hard drives at an average selling price of $61. Our non-GAAP gross margin was 28.5% and operating expenses totaled $542 million. Non-GAAP tax expense for the December quarter was $21 million or 5% of non-GAAP pretax income. On a non-GAAP basis, net income was $374 million or $1.60 per share. In the December quarter, we generated $598 million in cash from operations and our free cash flow totaled $449 million. Our CapEx totaled $149 million or 4% of revenue. We also declared a dividend in the amount of $0.50 per share. We closed the quarter with total cash and cash equivalents of $5.4 billion, of which approximately $500 million was held in the U.S. 
I will now provide an update regarding the cost savings we expect to realize as a result of the integration of our WD and HGST subsidiaries. All of my references in the following commentary are based on calendar year. To remind everyone, we previously indicated that we would realize $400 million of operating expense savings. We also said we would achieve additional meaningful savings from reductions in cost of goods sold. Finally, we indicated these savings would be obtained -- attained over a 1 to 2 years period. We have 3 main components in realizing these savings, including: asset and footprint reduction; product road map consolidation; and organization rationalization. During our last earnings call, we also mentioned that the quarterly baseline for operating expenses is $570 million from which these cost savings should be calculated. Following our initial integration planning, we continue to expect to realize $400 million of operating expense reduction per year on a run-rate basis by the end of 2017. The cost of goods sold, we expect to realize $250 million of synergy per year on a run-rate basis by the end of 2017. This will give us the opportunity to consistently operate in the top half of our existing gross margin model of 27% to 32%. We expect to achieve 50% of the synergy run rate by the end of 2016, and the balance by the end of 2017. We currently estimate cash cost to achieve these savings to be approximately $800 million. This estimate will continue to be refined as we finalize our cost reduction effort. Finally, we expect about 75% of this cost to be incurred in 2016 and the balance in 2017. 
Moving on to our guidance for the March quarter. We expect revenue to be in the range of $2.8 billion to $2.9 billion. On a non-GAAP basis, we expect: gross margin percentage to be up from our December quarter; operating expenses of approximately $500 million; we estimate non-GAAP earnings per share between $1.20 and $1.30. 
Operator, we are now ready to open the call for questions.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016

componenttext:
Operator, before we get to questions, I just wanted to correct, I had a misreading on my script. The strategic joint venture with Unisplendour will sell our storage in systems in China. I believe I misread that as Japan. So I just want to clarify that. 
We'll take people's questions now. Thank you.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016

componenttext: Okay. And then a follow-up on exabyte shipped. Some softness at the end of the year. Do you have much visibility? And what should we expect for the year from a seasonality perspective?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me take that question. So I think, relative to exabyte shipped, particularly in Capacity Enterprise, we did see it come in a little beneath our estimate of 35% growth year-on-year, came in around 32%. We would expect we would normalize back towards 35
componenttext: Let me take that question. So I think, relative to exabyte shipped, particularly in Capacity Enterprise, we did see it come in a little beneath our estimate of 35% growth year-on-year, came in around 32%. We would expect we would normalize back towards 35% of this year. We do have some visibility in terms of capital investments of our large customers. We'd expect the seasonality to move back towards something more typical where we would see something in the range of 55% to 60% in the second half of the calendar year and the balance in the first half.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Mehdi Hosseini  with SIG.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Mehdi Hosseini  with SIG.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Steve, I think everybody wants to hear what you have to say about in case Unis deal doesn't happen. In other words, [indiscernible] is not [indiscernible] by the end of February, and the SanDisk acquisition requires Western Digital's shareholder approval.
componenttext: Steve, I think everybody wants to hear what you have to say about in case Unis deal doesn't happen. In other words, [indiscernible] is not [indiscernible] by the end of February, and the SanDisk acquisition requires Western Digital's shareholder approval. And given the fact that you seem comfortable that SanDisk is going to close in the June quarter, what gives you confidence that your shareholders are going to approve this?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So there's kind of several questions on there. Let me clarify a couple of things. The first thing is that, the closing of the SanDisk acquisition is not contingent upon the closing of the Unis transaction. We'll be effective, if, for one reason or an
componenttext: Yes. So there's kind of several questions on there. Let me clarify a couple of things. The first thing is that, the closing of the SanDisk acquisition is not contingent upon the closing of the Unis transaction. We'll be effective, if, for one reason or another, the Unis transaction were not to close, would be that incremental shares would be issued to the SanDisk shareholders in that sort of a scenario. Under either event, we will be seeking shareholder vote on the transaction and the only question is, is will the number of shares exceed 20% of our outstanding shares. And so there is a scenario where we would seek a shareholder vote, but it may not require the issuance of 20% of our shareholders that either way, we will be conducting a proxy solicitation and vote on behalf of our shareholders. Regarding our confidence level in terms of shareholder, in terms of shareholder, our strong belief is, and very strong belief and strong conviction, is that this is the appropriate move for us to make for long term shareholder value creation. And we're confident in our ability to be able to get the necessary approvals from our shareholders to proceed with the transaction.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And just a quick follow-up. Your December quarter have Enterprise SSD revenue of $270 million, up 44% year-over-year. How should we think about that trending into calendar year '16?
componenttext: Great. And just a quick follow-up. Your December quarter have Enterprise SSD revenue of $270 million, up 44% year-over-year. How should we think about that trending into calendar year '16?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So I think we noted in our comments, there will be some dynamics happening in the first part of the year, but would expect a pause in that growth. And that's due to 2 factors. One is, will be typical IT spending being on a more cyclical basis or seas
componenttext: Yes. So I think we noted in our comments, there will be some dynamics happening in the first part of the year, but would expect a pause in that growth. And that's due to 2 factors. One is, will be typical IT spending being on a more cyclical basis or seasonal basis. And we do see additional competition in that space, which we would expect to have a effect on our trajectory.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: One of the things that we've said consistently is that we believe with our product portfolio on execution. We have the opportunity to continue to grow our Enterprise SSD revenue at a multiple of the market growth. And we continue to believe that, that wil
componenttext: One of the things that we've said consistently is that we believe with our product portfolio on execution. We have the opportunity to continue to grow our Enterprise SSD revenue at a multiple of the market growth. And we continue to believe that, that will be the case moving forward.

componenttextpreview: And then, you mentioned some visibility in the CapEx plans of large customers. I imagine, your commenting about cloud, Facebook gave aggressive guidance last night, if that makes sense. Would you expect WD's outside share of those large purchases among th
componenttext: And then, you mentioned some visibility in the CapEx plans of large customers. I imagine, your commenting about cloud, Facebook gave aggressive guidance last night, if that makes sense. Would you expect WD's outside share of those large purchases among the cloud service providers to remain? And do you even think that you could grow your share of those purchases this year?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. We think our value proposition with these customers, with our product portfolio, as well as the services we wrap around them will allow us to maintain our share position over time. Obviously, we have continued to execute well as we move forward, as w
componenttext: Yes. We think our value proposition with these customers, with our product portfolio, as well as the services we wrap around them will allow us to maintain our share position over time. Obviously, we have continued to execute well as we move forward, as we ramped the 10-terabyte product, et cetera. But we don't see anything that will particularly affect our aggregate share. Over time, we do expect some normalizing of the capacity point share.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the next question comes from Rich Kugele from Needham & Company.
componenttext: And the next question comes from Rich Kugele from Needham & Company.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: A couple of questions. First, we get a lot of inbound questions about interest rates relative to the deal. Can you just talk a little bit about relative to your original expectations to fund a SanDisk transaction and now, your ability to go and pay that d
componenttext: A couple of questions. First, we get a lot of inbound questions about interest rates relative to the deal. Can you just talk a little bit about relative to your original expectations to fund a SanDisk transaction and now, your ability to go and pay that debt level as the acquisition closes. And then secondly, in terms of the overall TAM, Mike, would you believe that the TAM hit the trough here in the March quarter? Or do you think that there's potential further weakness in the June quarter?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So, Rich, let me address. This is Steve. Let me address the first part of that question. One of the things I think that is important to emphasize is that when we evaluated the merits of doing the SanDisk transaction, there's a number of things that we loo
componenttext: So, Rich, let me address. This is Steve. Let me address the first part of that question. One of the things I think that is important to emphasize is that when we evaluated the merits of doing the SanDisk transaction, there's a number of things that we looked at. One is, is that we did -- we looked at various different scenarios from a business performance level. And we expected and anticipated that there could be some increased volatility from a market perspective, both from a macro perspective, as well as volatility as it relates to supply/demand dynamics in demand market. So we have stressed cases, we have base case scenarios, we also had bulk case scenarios. And in all those scenarios, the transaction prove to be value creating for our shareholders longer-term, so we're very confident in that regard. Additionally, as we approach the end of the year, we all know that we were looking at the potential for an increasing rate environment here in the U.S. So we factored in some expectation of rate increases in terms of that portion of our financing that would be affected by rate increases. And again, those rate increases, to date, have been within our expectations and we're confident that, that will remain the case. Additionally, the other thing that we've talked about is -- and there's additional details, to some degree in our S-4 filing, is that we expect to quickly deleverage our debt to the tune of specifically $3 million within a short period -- $3 billion -- sorry, $3 billion within a short period of time after the closing of the transaction. That deleveraging will incur in those areas in the market where we are more exposed to interest rate exposure. And so for those various reasons, I would emphasize that we continue to be very confident with regards to our ability to service the debt post close the SanDisk transaction. So I'll ask Mike to comment on TAM.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So to answer your question, Rich, I think we would see this as the low point of the year. Give you a little additional color on it. Of the sequential decline that we're projecting, we would chuck up roughly 2/3 of that to typical seasonality, as well as t
componenttext: So to answer your question, Rich, I think we would see this as the low point of the year. Give you a little additional color on it. Of the sequential decline that we're projecting, we would chuck up roughly 2/3 of that to typical seasonality, as well as the secular changes in the market, the balance of that attributed to macro conditions. And I think we would also say that given the environment around us, we are seeing a normal planning bias from the market to be more conservative around build expectations, as well as around inventory position. Now that's all factored into our outlook.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: The other thing, Rich, that I'd like to add to that is that we think that borrowing there being some other macroeconomic environment event that none of us can predict, that appears that the calendar first quarter will be the low point from a TAM perspecti
componenttext: The other thing, Rich, that I'd like to add to that is that we think that borrowing there being some other macroeconomic environment event that none of us can predict, that appears that the calendar first quarter will be the low point from a TAM perspective as it relates to calendar '16.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016

componenttext: And our next question comes from Aaron Rakers with Stifel, Nicolaus.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016

componenttext: Wanted to go to the reported results. I think this quarter, revenue was at the low end of your expectation, the gross margin. I think you'd initially guarded to be up a little bit sequentially. So I'm curious of what the underlying drivers were to the relative shortfall in the gross margin line. And I do have a follow-up.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So the relative shortfall in margin was due to two factors. One was product mix, which was the majority of the shortfall and the balance was lower volume impacting our absorption costs.
componenttext: So the relative shortfall in margin was due to two factors. One was product mix, which was the majority of the shortfall and the balance was lower volume impacting our absorption costs.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. And the mix comment is really due to slightly lower enterprise volumes.
componenttext: Yes. And the mix comment is really due to slightly lower enterprise volumes.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then, sticking on the gross margin line, as a follow-up. As you look at driving the synergy expectations that you expect of $250 million a year, and we look out to calendar 2017, relative to the mix change happening in the overall hard disk driv
componenttext: Okay. And then, sticking on the gross margin line, as a follow-up. As you look at driving the synergy expectations that you expect of $250 million a year, and we look out to calendar 2017, relative to the mix change happening in the overall hard disk drive industry, should we not be thinking that the gross margin line is at the high-end of the 27 to 32? And if not, why not?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, yes, I'm not so sure I would go to that point at this stage. And there's a lot of moving parts in terms of what happens with gross margin. They are -- the one thing that -- the biggest drag in terms of near-term on our gross margins, if you want to
componenttext: Well, yes, I'm not so sure I would go to that point at this stage. And there's a lot of moving parts in terms of what happens with gross margin. They are -- the one thing that -- the biggest drag in terms of near-term on our gross margins, if you want to call it that. I mean, let's be honest. We still continue to have strong gross margin performance, that has been weaker enterprise volumes. And it really has to do with what Mike was talking about in that the first half of calendar year 2015 had a higher mix of enterprise volumes and then, there was an absorption of that, those drives in the back half, we will see that kind of flip and go to normal seasonality in calendar year '16. So all things remaining equal, we should see our margins begin to benefit from that higher gross margin level as we exit calendar year 2016. But of course, there can be other factors, including pricing, which can impact things, there can be total volumes. And so I don't know if I want to be specific at this point as to when we'll end up closer to have that high end of that range. But we'll certainly going to do everything in our power to make it happen from an execution and from a product perspective.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016

componenttext: So the cash conversion cycle, we expect the impact to be minimum. We [indiscernible] have some impact on inventory, for example, but we would expect major improvement. In CapEx, being at the low-end of our range, even in the range of 4% is not a bad assumption.

And wanted to ask, you guys are going to seek a shareholder vote on the SanDisk transaction even if you don't need it? I.e. [indiscernible] 20% equity, right?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. That's correct. We will be seeking shareholder vote in any scenario. Yes, you're correct. Regarding our confidence level in terms of Sify's ruling is to be non-covered transaction, let me make a couple of comments on that. First thing is,  which we'v
componenttext: Yes. That's correct. We will be seeking shareholder vote in any scenario. Yes, you're correct. Regarding our confidence level in terms of Sify's ruling is to be non-covered transaction, let me make a couple of comments on that. First thing is,  which we've said repeatedly, is that we were very careful with regards to how we structure the transaction. And based upon that, we do not believe it's a covered transaction. Now that being said, this is up to the committee and U.S. government to decide. And frankly, that's very difficult at this stage to handicap. So I'm not sure that I want to go there in terms of trying to predict that. We want to certainly respect the decision-making process that the government goes through. We'll continue to engage with them and work with them. Clearly, we were very careful with how we structure the transaction.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016

And on the debt, if you want to look at the details of the debt, I will refer you to our S-4 filing, which has all the details of the debt, including the various instruments we'll be using, Monika.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016

componenttext: Then, Steve, maybe, could you talk about when do you plan to start using SanDisk  [indiscernible] in your Enterprise SSDs? So you could see the margin benefit?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, the short answer is as soon as we can, as soon as we possibly can. But obviously, we've got to close the transaction and begin more formally the integration process, et cetera, et cetera. So we don't have a specific time on that. But clearly, from a
componenttext: Well, the short answer is as soon as we can, as soon as we possibly can. But obviously, we've got to close the transaction and begin more formally the integration process, et cetera, et cetera. So we don't have a specific time on that. But clearly, from a financial and from a product perspective, we are highly motivated to make that happen as quickly as we can from a product development and lifecycle perspective.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So actually, there is [indiscernible] in there I guess. And then second question is just -- I appreciate the $400 million OpEx that you guys have been talking about all along, so that makes sense, but frankly, if you look at the TAM now, it's struct
componenttext: Okay. So actually, there is [indiscernible] in there I guess. And then second question is just -- I appreciate the $400 million OpEx that you guys have been talking about all along, so that makes sense, but frankly, if you look at the TAM now, it's structurally lower than it was a year or so ago. So would it not actually be fair to think that something beyond the $400 million would actually make really more sense at this stage? Or is it just the fact you'd rather leave that as a separate -- is that like a separate item, your HGST [indiscernible] you got something else?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, Rob, it's an interesting question because you're right, the $400 million we've been talking about for, frankly, 3.5, 4 years, if my memory's correct. The one thing that I would comments on is that subsequent to that period, as individual entiti
componenttext: Yes. Well, Rob, it's an interesting question because you're right, the $400 million we've been talking about for, frankly, 3.5, 4 years, if my memory's correct. The one thing that I would comments on is that subsequent to that period, as individual entities, there have been a number of OpEx reduction efforts that have occurred since that time. And so the actual reduction in our operating expenses from the close of the HGST WD transaction is actually much greater than an annual run rate of $400 million. For example, if you remember, [indiscernible] the WD's was engaged in the performance enterprise market. We have exited -- on the WD side, that business was exited. The OpEx savings were saved there. And so net, kind of apples-to-apples, we've actually reduced our OpEx more than that original $400 million that we talked about 3.5 years ago.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016

componenttext: As far as the cost saving goes, I was wondering if you could elaborate on cost savings beyond the shifty savings. At what point does a TAM get low enough where you would consider core capacity reductions to some degree? My first question, then I have a follow-up.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. We -- that's a fair question. We constantly look at that. Constantly look at that. And  again, kind of going back to the comment that I made to Rob question is that we have been, as the TAM has come down over the last few years, we have been continui
componenttext: Yes. We -- that's a fair question. We constantly look at that. Constantly look at that. And  again, kind of going back to the comment that I made to Rob question is that we have been, as the TAM has come down over the last few years, we have been continuing to rationalize our business to a lower volume base. So it's something that we dynamically and consistently evaluate and will continue to do so as we move forward.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just on the transaction, if I could. What's your sense of the Unis investment going through? If in the case that if it does cover the transaction, could that still be something that they're interested in to go through that process and continue with th
componenttext: And just on the transaction, if I could. What's your sense of the Unis investment going through? If in the case that if it does cover the transaction, could that still be something that they're interested in to go through that process and continue with their investment? And on the flip side, if they do wind up backing out for some reason or other consideration, is it possible to restructure the deal at this point to include more debt to lower the dilution in that second scenario of getting shareholder approval and buying Unis before the Unis transaction closes?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016

componenttext: Yes. Again, fair question. I'm not going to go there. At this point, our priority is working to satisfy the closing conditions as it relates to the Unis investment, including getting through the  process. To speculate at this point as to what happens if the U.S. government considers it to be a covered transaction, it's a little bit early to do that. So I'm not going to dare do that at this point.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016

componenttext: Our next question comes from Rod Hall, JPMorgan.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, my first question is regarding visibility. I wonder if you can just remind us what the lead times look like right now for drives? And what gives you confidence that you have visibility beyond March, given that market seems still unpredictable at
componenttext: I guess, my first question is regarding visibility. I wonder if you can just remind us what the lead times look like right now for drives? And what gives you confidence that you have visibility beyond March, given that market seems still unpredictable at this stage? And then, I have a follow-up.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So relative to the visibility of demand, we have some improving inside actually as this businesses mature, to plan for data center buildouts and what's going to be required to do that and what our proportion of that might be. So we continue to refine our
componenttext: So relative to the visibility of demand, we have some improving inside actually as this businesses mature, to plan for data center buildouts and what's going to be required to do that and what our proportion of that might be. So we continue to refine our engagement with those customers, such that we get a more insightful view into it. Relative to our drive leadtimes, it depends on the type of drive that we're talking about, anywhere from sort of 4 to 8 weeks would be a declining number, larger capacity being a bit longer and that's due to test drive.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And suffice it to say that given kind of the market volatility that we're seeing, the anxiousness that's been out there, we are clearly taking, as well as our customers, are taking a very cautious view with regards to the demand outlook, particularly here
componenttext: And suffice it to say that given kind of the market volatility that we're seeing, the anxiousness that's been out there, we are clearly taking, as well as our customers, are taking a very cautious view with regards to the demand outlook, particularly here in the near term. We believe that's the prudent thing to do. And -- but as always, in terms of the way that we manage our business, if demand happens to be higher than what we would expect, we'll be there to meet that opportunity.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And my follow-up was just -- I don't know if you guys are able to estimate this. But do you have any idea where inventory levels stand on the consumer side right now? In weeks or some sort of a duration sort of an estimate? And I guess, on enterpris
componenttext: Okay. And my follow-up was just -- I don't know if you guys are able to estimate this. But do you have any idea where inventory levels stand on the consumer side right now? In weeks or some sort of a duration sort of an estimate? And I guess, on enterprise, the same question, although I suppose that's much harder to estimate.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. We don't necessarily have any specific data on that other than to indicate we think that inventory levels are pretty healthy and what I mean by healthy is relatively lean and in pretty good shape. In other words, we don't think that there is any, cal
componenttext: Yes. We don't necessarily have any specific data on that other than to indicate we think that inventory levels are pretty healthy and what I mean by healthy is relatively lean and in pretty good shape. In other words, we don't think that there is any, call it, excess inventory. We have seen that through calendar year 2015, particularly with some of the -- in the PC market. We believe that, that's worked its way through the system. And so in that regard -- I mean this is a positive statement, we don't believe that there's an inventory overhang that the broader industry need to deal with.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016

componenttext: Okay. Fair enough. Maybe a quick follow up. Could you just clarify on the Enterprise SSD commentary. If growth will pause, did you actually expect the decline year-over-year? Seems a little aggressive just based on a product transition and along with that, when -- do you expect to show that 25% to 30% growth for calendar '16 still?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So -- I mean, if you look at -- we have $270 million of revenue last quarter, I believe a year ago, we had about $230 million of revenue. So we had -- we've got a tough compare. Obviously, we're still in the midst of the quarter, but it's possible th
componenttext: Yes. So -- I mean, if you look at -- we have $270 million of revenue last quarter, I believe a year ago, we had about $230 million of revenue. So we had -- we've got a tough compare. Obviously, we're still in the midst of the quarter, but it's possible that we might see our year-on-year revenue down a bit going into calendar Q1. But as far as the fiscal year, we would prefer not to be short-term focused. In terms of that and -- but it's really, when we talk about exceeding industry growth rates, it's over a longer period of time, a little bit too early to say whether or not our growth this year will accelerate or decelerate versus that. So it's not really an indication one way the other, but I prefer not to comment on that specifically.

componenttext: Yes. So I think one of the things that we need to continue need to focus on is the petabyte growth as opposed to the unit growth. Obviously, as we ship higher capacity points, we're going to ship, all things remaining equal, fewer units. And so as Mike indicated, we continue to see strong petabyte growth. The number that we're estimating is 32%, which is pretty -- well, longer term, 35%. This past year for us was 32%, which is pretty consistent with our expectation.

componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Mark Delaney with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Mark Delaney with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: First question is on your prepared remarks. You mentioned the combination of both cyclical and secular factors are causing the weaker outlook. Can you talk more on some of the secular changes that you're seeing and to what extent any secular pressure from
componenttext: First question is on your prepared remarks. You mentioned the combination of both cyclical and secular factors are causing the weaker outlook. Can you talk more on some of the secular changes that you're seeing and to what extent any secular pressure from flash versus hard drive has accelerated? And in particular, interested in any changes you're seeing in the enterprise segment?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So let me take client first. We see that continuing trend toward client SSDs, particularly in commercial class notebooks. It still remains within our planning guidelines. So we don't see it accelerating beyond our expectation. But it is steadily incr
componenttext: Yes. So let me take client first. We see that continuing trend toward client SSDs, particularly in commercial class notebooks. It still remains within our planning guidelines. So we don't see it accelerating beyond our expectation. But it is steadily increasing and it's certainly factored in the outlook. Relative to the enterprise, we do see, as evidenced by our own SAS Enterprise SSD strategy, we do see the beginnings of the incursion of Enterprise SSD into what is traditionally performance enterprise. And the way to think about that is it starts with the top, first with 15,000 RPM drives as being the first area for that conversion to begin, and then later on, it will be others. But we do see incursion in both of the segments, all of which is happening within the rate of -- that we have planned in our outlook. So that would be the color I can give you.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And then, a clarification question from the prior SanDisk comments. Yes, I know you said you used a range planning assumptions but clearly, there's a lot of the end market weakness and also, you have interest rates and other factors.
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And then, a clarification question from the prior SanDisk comments. Yes, I know you said you used a range planning assumptions but clearly, there's a lot of the end market weakness and also, you have interest rates and other factors. Is the comment that you made on the last or on the SanDisk call about your 10% accretion, is that still the right number for us to be thinking about? Or has that changed?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's still the correct number.
componenttext: It's still the correct number.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just [indiscernible]. The first one is, one of the most intriguing questions that we've got in over the last few months with regards to the SanDisk deal is around Toshiba's ability -- or I guess, sorry, Toshiba's positioning, currently, 3D NAND IP develop
componenttext: Just [indiscernible]. The first one is, one of the most intriguing questions that we've got in over the last few months with regards to the SanDisk deal is around Toshiba's ability -- or I guess, sorry, Toshiba's positioning, currently, 3D NAND IP development. So, Steve, I was just wondering if you could remind us in that regard, the due diligence that you guys did leading up to the announcement of the deal and your comfort in that regard, with regards to 3D NAND. That will be awesome, and then I have a follow-up.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So just to remind everybody, as part of our due diligence, as it relates to the SanDisk acquisition, is that we did extensive technical due diligence related to where SanDisk/Toshiba was with regards to the 3D NAND transition of that. We were very c
componenttext: Sure. So just to remind everybody, as part of our due diligence, as it relates to the SanDisk acquisition, is that we did extensive technical due diligence related to where SanDisk/Toshiba was with regards to the 3D NAND transition of that. We were very comfortable with where they were at and continue to be very comfortable with where they're with their transition and are particularly encouraged by the recent announcements that they made in conjunction with their earnings announcement, which indicates that they are now commercially shipping. There's 3D 48-layer 3D NAND product into the marketplace.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then, I guess my follow-up is, commensurate with your TAM comments in September -- I'm sorry, March being the calendar year low, could you share with us what your PC view is this year? And to what extent, if any, we may be able to see some enterprise
componenttext: And then, I guess my follow-up is, commensurate with your TAM comments in September -- I'm sorry, March being the calendar year low, could you share with us what your PC view is this year? And to what extent, if any, we may be able to see some enterprise refresher, commercial refresh as we get to the second half of the year?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So relative to -- Mike, address the enterprise refresh. But in terms of PC, we have not been bullish on the PC market for a while. And we would see, generally speaking, the rate of decline on the PC market to be a bit less than what it's been this past ca
componenttext: So relative to -- Mike, address the enterprise refresh. But in terms of PC, we have not been bullish on the PC market for a while. And we would see, generally speaking, the rate of decline on the PC market to be a bit less than what it's been this past calendar year. And may be something in 6%, 5%, something like that kind of range on a full year basis. As I indicated, we continue to be not particularly optimistic from an overall perspective regarding what's happening in the PC market. And our financial plans and future plans are not highly contingent on that. Mike?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So I think on an enterprise outlook basis, I sort of referenced it. The past Enterprise segment, we see that continuing to progress. We see an increasing adoption of helium class drives as the people deploying infrastructure realize the benefits of t
componenttext: Yes. So I think on an enterprise outlook basis, I sort of referenced it. The past Enterprise segment, we see that continuing to progress. We see an increasing adoption of helium class drives as the people deploying infrastructure realize the benefits of the TCO that, that technology offers. We articulated that growth rate we would expect to cross that total segment. Relative to the performance category, I just talked a little bit about that. We do see the continuing penetration of flash based products into that marketplace. We see that continuing through the balance of the year as evidenced by a number of people in their systems announcements most recently. We would expect that to benefit from that, obviously, with our strategy of being media agnostic as we move forward with completion of SanDisk acquisition.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So thank you for joining us today. In summary, we continue to execute well in a challenging environment. We're taking proactive steps to maintain and extend our cost leadership in the HDTV industry. We're also pleased with our progress on our strategic
componenttext:
So thank you for joining us today. 
In summary, we continue to execute well in a challenging environment. We're taking proactive steps to maintain and extend our cost leadership in the HDTV industry. We're also pleased with our progress on our strategic efforts to diversify and strengthen the company for the long term, including the acquisition of SanDisk. We look forward to keeping you informed of our progress on all fronts. 
Thank you for joining us.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: That concludes today's conference call. Thank you for joining, and you may now disconnect.
componenttext: That concludes today's conference call. Thank you for joining, and you may now disconnect.

Good afternoon, and thank you for standing by. Welcome to Western Digital's financial results for the second quarter of fiscal year 2016. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this call is being recorded. 
Now, I'll turn the call over to Mr. Bob Blair. You may begin.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and good afternoon. This conference call contains forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Federal Securities Laws. Such forward-looking statements are based upon management's current expectations and include known and unknown risks
componenttext:
Thank you, and good afternoon. This conference call contains forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Federal Securities Laws. Such forward-looking statements are based upon management's current expectations and include known and unknown risks, uncertainties and other factors, many of which Western Digital is unable to predict or control, that may cause our actual results, performance or game plans to differ materially from those expressed or implied by such forward-looking statements. This conference call does not constitute an offer to purchase or the solicitation of an offer to sell any securities or a solicitation of any vote or approval in connection with the pending merger with SanDisk. 
Western Digital filed a Form S-4 registration statement with the SEC that includes proxy statements of SanDisk and Western Digital and a prospectus of Western Digital regarding the merger. After the joint proxy statement prospectus is declared effective, Western Digital and SanDisk will mail the definitive joint proxy statement prospectus to the respective shareholders. Investors and shareholders should read the joint proxy statements and prospectus carefully when it becomes available, because it contains important information about the merger. 
In addition, Western Digital, SanDisk and their respective directors, executive officers and certain other members of management and employees may be soliciting proxies from their respective shareholders in favor of the proposed transaction. You can find information about Western Digital directors and executive officers in Western Digital's most recent proxy statement and about SanDisk's directors and executive officers in SanDisk's most recent proxy statement. You may obtain a copy of these documents through the SEC's website or in the Western Digital and SanDisk websites. 
Further references will be made during this call to non-GAAP financial measures. Reconciliations of the difference -- differences between the non-GAAP measures we provide during this call to the comparable GAAP financial measures are included in the quarterly fact sheet posted in the Investor Relations section of our websites.
I also want to highlight that the information provided during this call today regarding the savings we realized as a result of the integration of our WD and HGST subsidiaries and the expected costs to achieve such savings are included in the quarterly fact sheet posted in the Investor Relations section of our website. 
[Operator Instructions] 
I also want to note that copies of remarks from today's call will be available on the Investors Section some time later after this call. 
And now, I'd like to turn the call over to Steve Milligan, Chief Executive Officer.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us.  With me today are Mike Cordano, our President and Chief Operating Officer; and Olivier Leonetti, our Chief Financial Officer. After my opening remarks, Olivier will give additional commentary on our December
componenttext:
Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us.  With me today are Mike Cordano, our President and Chief Operating Officer; and Olivier Leonetti, our Chief Financial Officer. After my opening remarks, Olivier will give additional commentary on our December quarter performance and our outlook for the March quarter. He will also provide an update on the expected integration savings, resulting from the lift of almost all of the restrictions MOFCOM had placed on our business. 
We continue to execute well as we manage our business within an increasingly challenging global economic environment. We reported revenue of $3.3 billion, non-GAAP gross margin of 28.5% and non-GAAP diluted earnings per share of $1.60. We also had strong free cash flow performance of $449 million, and our storage shipments for the December quarter grew to 69.1 exabytes. The HDD TAM in the December quarter came in somewhat below our expectations. The gaming sector was weaker, and enterprise volumes were a bit lighter than expected. We anticipate weak demand in the March quarter, resulting in a hard drive TAM of approximately 100 million units. 
The main factors behind this forecast are the expected combination of seasonal and secular trends as well as increased caution among customers and end markets relative to challenging global economic conditions. Being able to integrate our HGST and WD subsidiaries and transform into one company, affords us the opportunity to optimize our business model for both the near and long term. We are taking a number of important steps in this context. We are reducing our cost base through a series of planned actions, including the elimination of redundancy in functions, products and facilities. Olivier will provide additional detail on the magnitude and timing of the integration-related savings, but let me cite a few examples. 
Last week, we announced the closure of our head wafer manufacturing facility in Ottawa, Japan: 1 of our 3 head wafer facilities. We are streamlining our product roadmap by focusing our efforts to eliminate redundancy and optimize the products we offer, resulting in the elimination of a minimum of 6 programs. And we recently set our new leadership team, with a plan to complete our new company-wide organizational structure in the June quarter. We believe this aggressive approach to reduce our cost structure will maintain and extend our cost leadership in the hard drive industry. 
Turning to the longer term. We remain focused on transforming Western Digital into one of the world's leading companies in the large, rapidly changing and high-growth storage industry. We continue to believe in the unabated growth in the creation of data, in the amount of data being stored and in our ability to create long-term value for our customers and shareholders. We continue to diversify our revenue base in the higher growth areas, aligned with cloud storage and the third platform of computing. This includes building on our track record of innovation in Capacity Enterprise, most recently, with our leadership in helium sealed drives. Our helium drives shipments totaled a record 1.5 million in the December quarter, including initial shipments of our 10-terabyte drive, our third-generation helium drive. First shipped by Western Digital in 2013, we are pleased with the success and wider adoption of helium technology and enterprise IT, as it marks the shift for hard drive makers to deliver value-added storage solutions to customers based on a value proposition of better total cost of ownership.
Our Enterprise SSD revenue grew to $270 million in the December quarter. While we continue to believe Enterprise SSD will be one of our main growth drivers, we expect to see a pause in our growth in the March quarter, given typical seasonal factors in enterprise IT spending and as we proceed through a SAS product transition. And we continue to see good traction in our Active Archive systems business, with several wins in Tier 2 cloud infrastructure, backup and archive applications and other vertical markets. 
Regarding the SanDisk acquisition. We are pleased with the progress we are  making in obtaining required regulatory approvals. It has always been our goal to close the acquisition as soon as possible, and as noted in our Form 8-K filing earlier this month, we have competed the FTC review in the U.S. I would also note that the FTC completed its review without issuing a second request, which we see as confirmation of our view that this transaction is pro competitive. We have also received recent approvals from antitrust agencies in Singapore and Japan. Based on our work with other agencies around the world, we currently anticipate that the acquisition will close in the June quarter.
I would like to emphasize the importance of the acquisition of SanDisk to our overall strategic plan. Once we close the acquisition, we will have the broadest set of products to offer our customers, a deep technology base across nonvolatile memory and rotating magnetic media and an expanded addressable market. 
On the Unisplendour investment, we and Unisplendour continue to work with CFIUS as they review the proposed investment in Western Digital. CFIUS has not yet reached a decision on whether the investment is a covered transaction. We continue to believe that we have structured this investment carefully in order to avoid that result. Given CFIUS' heavy caseload towards the end of last year, we asked to withdraw and refile our notice in order to provide additional time for us to engage with them on our case. CFIUS agreed to our request, and we refiled in January. We now expect A decision from CFIUS sometime in February. Our strategic joint venture with Unisplendour to sell our storage systems in Japan is proceeding as planned. We successfully negotiated its terms, including operational and governance plans in late 2015. And with those complete, we are now in the process of satisfying certain closing conditions while simultaneously recruiting and staffing the JV.
I'm very excited about the company's future and our ability to create long-term value for our customers, shareholders and employees. 
Olivier will now provide his commentary before we take your questions.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Steve.  Our revenue for the December quarter was $3.3 billion. We shipped a total of 49.7 million hard drives at an average selling price of $61. Our non-GAAP gross margin was 28.5%, and operating expenses totaled $542 million. Non-GAAP tax exp
componenttext:
Thank you, Steve.  Our revenue for the December quarter was $3.3 billion. We shipped a total of 49.7 million hard drives at an average selling price of $61. Our non-GAAP gross margin was 28.5%, and operating expenses totaled $542 million. Non-GAAP tax expense for the December quarter was $21 million or 5% of non-GAAP pretax income. On a non-GAAP basis, net income was $374 million or $1.60 per share. In the December quarter, we generated $598 million in cash from operations, and our free cash flow totaled $449 million. Our CapEx totaled $149 million or 4% of revenue. We also declared a dividend in the amount of $0.50 per share. We closed the quarter with total cash and cash equivalents of $5.4 billion, of which approximately $500 million was held in the U.S. 
I will now provide an update regarding the cost savings we expect to realize as a result of the integration of our WD and HGST subsidiaries. All of my references in the following commentary are based on calendar years. To remind everyone, we previously indicated that we would realize $400 million of operating expense savings. We also said we would achieve additional meaningful savings from reductions in cost of goods sold. 
Finally, we indicated these savings would be obtained over a 1 to 2 years period. We have 3 main components in realizing these savings, including: asset and footprint reduction; product roadmap consolidation; and organization rationalization. During our last earnings call, we also mentioned that the quarterly baseline for operating expenses is $570 million from which these cost savings should be calculated. 
Following our initial integration planning, we continue to expect to realize $400 million of operating expense reduction per year on a run-rate basis by the end of 2017. The cost of goods sold, we expect to realize $250 million of synergy per year on a run-rate basis by the end of 2017. This would give us the opportunity to consistently operate in the top half of our existing gross margin model of 27% to 32%. We expect to achieve 50% of the synergy run rate by the end of 2016 and the balance by the end of 2017. We currently estimate cash cost to achieve these savings to be approximately $800 million. This estimate will continue to be refined as we finalize our cost reduction efforts. Finally, we expect about 75% of this cost to be incurred in 2016 and the balance in 2017.
Moving on to our guidance for the March quarter. We expect revenue to be in the range of $2.8 billion to $2.9 billion. On a non-GAAP basis, we expect gross margin percentage to be up from our December quarter, operating expenses of approximately $500 million, we estimate non-GAAP earnings per share between $1.20 and $1.30. 
Operator, we are now ready to open the call for questions.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016

componenttext:
Operator, before we get the questions, I just wanted to correct, I had a misreading of my script. The strategic joint venture with Unisplendour will sell our storage systems in China. I believe I misread that as Japan. So I just want to clarify that.
We will take people's questions now. Thank you.

componenttext: Okay. And then a follow-up on exabytes shipped, some softness at the end of the year. Do you have much visibility? And what should we expect for the year from a seasonality perspective?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me take that question. So I think, relative to exabytes shipped, particularly in Capacity Enterprise, we did see it come in a little beneath our estimate of 35% growth year-on-year, came in around 32%. We would expect we would normalize back towards 3
componenttext: Let me take that question. So I think, relative to exabytes shipped, particularly in Capacity Enterprise, we did see it come in a little beneath our estimate of 35% growth year-on-year, came in around 32%. We would expect we would normalize back towards 35% this year. We do have some visibility in terms of capital investments of our large customers. We'd expect the seasonality to move back towards something more typical where we would see something in the range of 55% to 60% in the second half of the calendar year and the balance in the first half.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Mehdi Hosseini  with SIG.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Mehdi Hosseini  with SIG.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Steve, I think everybody wants to hear what you have to say about in case Unis deal doesn't happen. In other words, if CFIUS approval is not obtained by the end of February, then the SanDisk acquisition requires Western Digital shareholders' approval. And
componenttext: Steve, I think everybody wants to hear what you have to say about in case Unis deal doesn't happen. In other words, if CFIUS approval is not obtained by the end of February, then the SanDisk acquisition requires Western Digital shareholders' approval. And given the fact that you seem comfortable that the SanDisk is going to close in the June quarter, what gives you confidence that your shareholders are going to approve this?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So there's kind of several questions on there. Let me clarify a couple of things. The first thing is that, the closing of the SanDisk acquisition is not contingent upon the closing of the Unis transaction. What will be affected, if for one reason or
componenttext: Yes. So there's kind of several questions on there. Let me clarify a couple of things. The first thing is that, the closing of the SanDisk acquisition is not contingent upon the closing of the Unis transaction. What will be affected, if for one reason or another, the Unis transaction were not to close, would be that incremental shares would be issued to the SanDisk shareholders in that sort of a scenario. Under either event, we will be seeking shareholder vote on the transaction and the only question is, will the number of shares exceed 20% of our outstanding shares? And so there is a scenario where we would seek a shareholder vote, but it may not require the issuance of 20% of our shareholders that either way, we will be conducting a proxy solicitation and vote on behalf of our shareholders. Regarding our confidence level in terms of shareholders, our strong belief is, and very strong belief and strong conviction, is that this is the appropriate move for us to make for long-term shareholder value creation. And we're confident in our ability to be able to get the necessary approvals from our shareholders to proceed with the transaction.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And just a quick follow-up. Your December quarter had Enterprise SSD revenue of $270 million, up 44% year-over-year. How should we think about that trending into calendar year '16?
componenttext: Great. And just a quick follow-up. Your December quarter had Enterprise SSD revenue of $270 million, up 44% year-over-year. How should we think about that trending into calendar year '16?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So I think we noted in our comments, there will be some dynamics happening in the first part of the year, but would expect a pause in that growth. And that's due to 2 factors: one is, it would be typical IT spending being on a more cyclical basis or
componenttext: Yes. So I think we noted in our comments, there will be some dynamics happening in the first part of the year, but would expect a pause in that growth. And that's due to 2 factors: one is, it would be typical IT spending being on a more cyclical basis or seasonal basis. And we do see additional competition in that space, which we would expect to have a effect on our trajectory.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I think say, one of the things that we've said consistently is that we believe with our product portfolio on execution, we have the opportunity to continue to grow our Enterprise SSD revenue at a multiple of the market growth. And we continue to belie
componenttext: And I think say, one of the things that we've said consistently is that we believe with our product portfolio on execution, we have the opportunity to continue to grow our Enterprise SSD revenue at a multiple of the market growth. And we continue to believe that, that will be the case moving forward.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016

componenttext: Would you elaborate on the market growth?

componenttext: We've been assuming about 25% to 30% CAGR over the next 5 years, and that's the whole revenue statement.

componenttext: The next question comes from Katy Huberty with Morgan Stanley.

componenttext: And then, you mentioned some visibility into CapEx plans of large customers. I imagine, your commenting about cloud, Facebook gave aggressive guidance last night, if that makes sense. Would you expect WD's outside share of those large purchases among the cloud service providers to remain? And do you even think that you could grow your share of those purchases this year?

componenttext: Yes. We think our value proposition to these customers, with our product portfolio as well as the services we wrap around them will allow us to maintain our share position over time. Obviously, we have continued to execute well as we move forward, as we ramped the 10-terabyte product, et cetera. But we don't see anything that will particularly affect our aggregate share. Over time, we do expect some normalizing of the capacity point share.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the next question comes from Rich Kugele from Needham & Company.
componenttext: And the next question comes from Rich Kugele from Needham & Company.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: A couple of questions. First, we get a lot of inbound questions about interest rates relative to the deal. Can you just talk a little bit about relative to your original expectations to fund a SanDisk transaction and now on your ability to go and pay that
componenttext: A couple of questions. First, we get a lot of inbound questions about interest rates relative to the deal. Can you just talk a little bit about relative to your original expectations to fund a SanDisk transaction and now on your ability to go and pay that debt level as the acquisition closes? And then secondly, in terms of the overall TAM, Mike, would you believe that the TAM hit the trough here in the March quarter? Or do you think that there is potential further weakness in the June quarter?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So, Rich, let me address -- this is Steve. Let me address the first part of that question. One of the things I think that is important to emphasize is that when we evaluated the merits of doing the SanDisk transaction, there's a number of things that we l
componenttext: So, Rich, let me address -- this is Steve. Let me address the first part of that question. One of the things I think that is important to emphasize is that when we evaluated the merits of doing the SanDisk transaction, there's a number of things that we looked at. One is, is that we did -- we looked at various different scenarios from a business performance level. And we expected and anticipated that there could be some increased volatility from a market perspective, both from a macro perspective as well as volatility as it relates to supply/demand dynamics in demand market. So we have stressed cases, we have base case scenarios, we also had bull case scenarios. And in all those scenarios, the transaction proved to be value creating for our shareholders longer term, so we're very confident in that regard. Additionally, as we approach the end of the year, we all know that we were looking at the potential for an increasing rate environment here in the U.S. So we factored in some expectation of rate increases in terms of that portion of our financing that would be affected by rate increases. And again, those rate increases, to date, have been within our expectations and we're confident that, that will remain the case. Additionally, the other thing that we've talked about is -- and there is additional details, to some degree in our S-4 filing, is that we expect to quickly deleverage our debt to the tune of specifically $3 million within a short period -- $3 billion -- sorry, $3 billion within a short period of time after the closing of the transaction. That deleveraging will incur in those areas in the market where we are more exposed to interest rate exposure. And so for those various reasons, I would emphasize that we continue to be very confident with regards to our ability to service the debt post close of the SanDisk transaction. So I'll ask Mike to comment on TAM.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so to answer your question, Rich, I think we would see this as the  low point of the year. I give you a little additional color on it. Of the sequential decline that we're projecting, we would chalk up roughly 2/3 of that to typical seasonality as we
componenttext: Yes, so to answer your question, Rich, I think we would see this as the  low point of the year. I give you a little additional color on it. Of the sequential decline that we're projecting, we would chalk up roughly 2/3 of that to typical seasonality as well as the secular changes in the market, the balance of that attributed to macro conditions. And I think we would also say that given the environment around us, we are seeing a normal planning bias from the markets to be more conservative around build expectations as well as around inventory position. Now all that's all factored into our outlook.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: The other thing, Rich, that I'd like to add to that is that we think that borrowing there being some other macroeconomic event that none of us can predict that it appears that the calendar first quarter will be the low point from a TAM perspective as it r
componenttext: The other thing, Rich, that I'd like to add to that is that we think that borrowing there being some other macroeconomic event that none of us can predict that it appears that the calendar first quarter will be the low point from a TAM perspective as it relates to calendar '16.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Aaron Rakers with Stifel, Nicolaus.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Aaron Rakers with Stifel, Nicolaus.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
