componenttext: One additional comment on the debt. Obviously, the cost of the debt for secured bond and unsecured bond is public. They wanted to say that the average rate for the total debt will be significantly lower than the rate of the bonds and we'll get back to you on the short order.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Rich Kugele of Needham & Company.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Rich Kugele of Needham & Company.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: A few questions. If you could just talk first, Steve, you did touch on the weakness in NPCs and enterprise. But if you could just elaborate on both the demand and pricing trends by category? And then I have a follow-up.
componenttext: A few questions. If you could just talk first, Steve, you did touch on the weakness in NPCs and enterprise. But if you could just elaborate on both the demand and pricing trends by category? And then I have a follow-up.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. I'll comment on it and then Mike Cordano might want to add a little bit as well as we go through. From a demand perspective, as I indicated, from an aggregate-demand perspective, things came in pretty much the way that we had expected, right? We had
componenttext: Sure. I'll comment on it and then Mike Cordano might want to add a little bit as well as we go through. From a demand perspective, as I indicated, from an aggregate-demand perspective, things came in pretty much the way that we had expected, right? We had called a 100 unit TAM and came in at whatever 99.8, that's our estimate, right. We haven't seen Toshiba's numbers yet. And within that, I would say that the PC market obviously, remains weak and a bit weaker than what we expected. Now that being said, I'm going to sound like I'm contradicting myself, we had hedged that a little bit because we been pretty bearish in the PC market for a while. Clearly, the PC market remains a bit weaker than what we expected. I would say that from a demand perspective that the area of, if you want to it biggest surprise, was that performance enterprise was weaker than we expected. Mike might comment a little bit on what we're seeing thereafter I kind of get a view on what we saw from a pricing perspective. And then there were some other areas that we're may be kind of slightly better than what we expected, where in aggregate it came out to kind of 100 million unit TAM number. Now from a pricing perspective, kind of a mixed bag there. On the positive side, we were able to increase our pricing in the 2.5-inch market, both oriented towards notebook as well as in gaming. So we were able to increase our prices and those price increases have stuck and are reflected in our go-forward estimates as it relates to our financials. On the negative side is that we saw steeper than anticipated price declines in the enterprise market, both in performance enterprise and even more specifically, in Capacity Enterprise and to be even more specific on that, in the 4 8 terabyte capacity points. And you can see that if you look at our margins, where they were short of our expectations and we were down quarter-on-quarter, that is directly correlated to what we saw from a pricing perspective. And by the way, further to that, we actually lost share in the enterprise market as we chose not to participate in some of those more steeper declines from a pricing perspective. Now what we're doing as a consequence to that is that we're taking the action from our standpoint because we want to make sure that we've got sufficient dollars to reinvest back into our business to continue to innovate and provide compelling products for our customers, we are making selective price increases in certain enterprise markets. At this point, we're not sure if they're going to stick, but we're certainly hoping that they do. And with that, I'll ask Mike to comment a bit on performance enterprise demand dynamics.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Rich, so I think it's important to start to delineating the performance enterprise marketplace. And if you think about it as those performance enterprise drives that sell into the storage system marketplaces versus the server marketplace, what we have see
componenttext: Rich, so I think it's important to start to delineating the performance enterprise marketplace. And if you think about it as those performance enterprise drives that sell into the storage system marketplaces versus the server marketplace, what we have seen for some time is the decline in 15,000 RPM that continues, that trend down continues. We are now seeing some more trending down happening in the 10K market quarter-over-quarter. But the pronounced reduction we see is really in the storage segment of the marketplace. I think that's reflected in what we see people doing with all flash arrays and whatnot. So going forward, we think we'll see accelerating trend, downward trends, within the storage segment, but a more stable profile within the server segment. And we'll be, as Steve said, looking the way that portfolio shapes up and position ourselves appropriately.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And then lastly, Olivier, I know it's early. But in light of recent actions by the Treasury Department on initially, I guess, tax conversions, but it could potentially have broader impacts on just broad cross-border transfers and oth
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And then lastly, Olivier, I know it's early. But in light of recent actions by the Treasury Department on initially, I guess, tax conversions, but it could potentially have broader impacts on just broad cross-border transfers and other things. Do you see any impact at this point on the way you wanted to normalize the tax rate between the 2 companies over time?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Rich, obviously, this recent notice is a draft, which is currently being opened for comments. And while it's premature for us to provide more details of this stage, we feel comfortable with the structure of our transaction. So no change at this stage,
componenttext: So Rich, obviously, this recent notice is a draft, which is currently being opened for comments. And while it's premature for us to provide more details of this stage, we feel comfortable with the structure of our transaction. So no change at this stage, Rich.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Aaron Rakers with Stifel, Nicolaus.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Aaron Rakers with Stifel, Nicolaus.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Couple of questions also if I can. First of all, as we look at the capacity shipment growth for the industry, it's continued to be relatively slow. I was curious if you could help us understand or delineate between what you've seen capacity shipment growt
componenttext: Couple of questions also if I can. First of all, as we look at the capacity shipment growth for the industry, it's continued to be relatively slow. I was curious if you could help us understand or delineate between what you've seen capacity shipment growth wise in the PC market as well as CE and relative to the overall enterprise market. And then in the context of the pricing environment, I'm curious of how you would frame the discussion around the gross margin differential between those segments.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Let me touch on that capacity growth. So we continue to see, again looking on an annualized basis, considering the calendar year, Capacity Enterprise continues to trend at this 35% run rate, last year looks like and the data is preliminary that the
componenttext: Okay. Let me touch on that capacity growth. So we continue to see, again looking on an annualized basis, considering the calendar year, Capacity Enterprise continues to trend at this 35% run rate, last year looks like and the data is preliminary that the data came in around 34%. We would expect this year also to be tracking to that number, may be slightly greater. We'll see how the year pans out. Now the one thing I should point out, we discussed this last time, is calendar '15 was inverted relative to seasonality stronger in the first half, weaker in the second. This year is more traditional seasonality, where we expect strength in the backend of the year and that's further supported by what a number of the hyperscale companies I've talked about relative to expected CapEx. So that growth remains as expected. The softness and capacity shipments really is across the other markets, led by the PC market as well as this news that we discussed today on performance enterprise.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And any comments on the relative margin differential between the segments?
componenttext: Okay. And any comments on the relative margin differential between the segments?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Aaron, I'm not sure there's any new commentary. Obviously, the higher margin segments for us and -- is in the enterprise area, Capacity Enterprise performance. And then although still attractive margins, the low end of that would be client-related activit
componenttext: Aaron, I'm not sure there's any new commentary. Obviously, the higher margin segments for us and -- is in the enterprise area, Capacity Enterprise performance. And then although still attractive margins, the low end of that would be client-related activity as well as in gaming. And so there's really no change in terms of our margin hierarchy that we've talked about previously.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Amit Daryanani with RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Amit Daryanani with RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I have a question and a follow-up as well. If we could just start with for the June quarter, you guys, I think, are looking at the TAM or [indiscernible] declined by about 6%. Is that entirely going to come from units? Is there a pricing dynamic as well?
componenttext: I have a question and a follow-up as well. If we could just start with for the June quarter, you guys, I think, are looking at the TAM or [indiscernible] declined by about 6%. Is that entirely going to come from units? Is there a pricing dynamic as well? And any segment information you could provide in terms of what's getting incrementally soft in June would be helpful.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So if you look at -- so we would say that the TAM to be more specific will be about 95 million units for the June quarter. And the primary reason for that is continued weakness in terms of the PC market and not only that, but frankly, from our standpoint
componenttext: So if you look at -- so we would say that the TAM to be more specific will be about 95 million units for the June quarter. And the primary reason for that is continued weakness in terms of the PC market and not only that, but frankly, from our standpoint and as well as our customers are a very cautious view with regards to that market, not a lot of bullish views out there on the PC market as well as continued softness in terms of the performance enterprise, those are the only ones that I think are really kind of worthy of calling out. We've got some other puts and takes in terms of normal seasonal trends that we see from a Q1 to Q2. But the primary reason for that decline is really those 2 factors that I called out. The other thing that I would add to that is that if you go back to our prior conference call, we had anticipated that the March quarter would be the low point of the year from a TAM perspective. Obviously, that had not borne itself out assuming that TAM turns out to be in 95 million. And the primary reason for that is again because of weaker PC sales and softer demand for performance, for traditional performance enterprise hard drives.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Perfect. And if I just follow-up on the enterprise SSD side, revenues were down, I think, 11% year-over-year. Can you talk about it being the last quarter somewhat. But it seems a little bit more severe than I would have thought and what some of your peer
componenttext: Perfect. And if I just follow-up on the enterprise SSD side, revenues were down, I think, 11% year-over-year. Can you talk about it being the last quarter somewhat. But it seems a little bit more severe than I would have thought and what some of your peers have been talking. So I'm just wondering, could you just talk about what's happening within that segment? And how do you see that transpire for the rest of the year?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think we talked about a product transition underway, certainly, we're seeing increased competitiveness there. But for us, we're in the midst of a product transition, which we'll be through as we progressed -- we will get through as we progress thro
componenttext: Yes. I think we talked about a product transition underway, certainly, we're seeing increased competitiveness there. But for us, we're in the midst of a product transition, which we'll be through as we progressed -- we will get through as we progress through the year so that largely accounts for the difference you're talking about.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: By the way, just kind of give you some insight to that. We had always expected and we messaged in sort of telegraph decrease in terms of that revenue. And the decrease was more or less consistent with what we expected and not only that, we probably we did
componenttext: By the way, just kind of give you some insight to that. We had always expected and we messaged in sort of telegraph decrease in terms of that revenue. And the decrease was more or less consistent with what we expected and not only that, we probably we did a little bit better than we thought. So it's not concerning for us, it's something that we expected. And it just has to do with the normal product transition that we're working through on our end with our customers.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I'll add a little more color, I think relative to strategic engagements, they remain very well intact and we think we'll get through this in sort of the normal course of thing. So no ongoing impact that we'd expect once we get through the transition.
componenttext: And I'll add a little more color, I think relative to strategic engagements, they remain very well intact and we think we'll get through this in sort of the normal course of thing. So no ongoing impact that we'd expect once we get through the transition.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Mehdi Hosseini also scanner.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Mehdi Hosseini also scanner.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Steve, the characterization of your customer and trend in their buying behavior is changing the traditional enterprises haven't been affected over the past years and replaced by the cloud guys, and the cloud guys are pushing for more of an array procureme
componenttext: Steve, the characterization of your customer and trend in their buying behavior is changing the traditional enterprises haven't been affected over the past years and replaced by the cloud guys, and the cloud guys are pushing for more of an array procurement. In that context, do you see the change in your customer characterization have an impact in how you define different segments of the market?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Go ahead, Mike.
componenttext: Go ahead, Mike.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I think we absolutely see a transition between our customers, but that's really reflected mostly by moving from platform to traditional client/server markets to cloud-based architectures, as we talked about in the prepared remarks. So that architectura
componenttext: So I think we absolutely see a transition between our customers, but that's really reflected mostly by moving from platform to traditional client/server markets to cloud-based architectures, as we talked about in the prepared remarks. So that architectural shift is happening and with that, that ratio of business is trending towards more of the cloud-based architecture when we talked about enterprise. So as we look at the customers certainly, is that the relative revenue is changing. The way we look at them and engage them is also changing, and that's all contemplated within our business and our modeling going forward. So, yes, to your question in both from a customer transition as well as which architectures are we shipping into and how workloads are migrating.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Which makes it lumpy? And a follow-up has to do with demand, have you already started the kind of qualification as you go through the integration of SanDisk? And how should we think about the timing associated? Because as you go to the qualification for y
componenttext: Which makes it lumpy? And a follow-up has to do with demand, have you already started the kind of qualification as you go through the integration of SanDisk? And how should we think about the timing associated? Because as you go to the qualification for your own, for the existing SSD products as well as consolidating enterprise SSDs once SanDisk is integrated, I imagine there would be a time or a lagging effect how you get your arms around it. Is that going to -- do we need to wait till the July conference call to get more clarification? Or how should we think about this timing? Any color you can provide will be appreciated.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, a few comments there. I mean, the first thing is, no, we have not begun any qualification or integration-related activities for our products. And I think it's important that to note that we continue to operate as 2 separate companies. And so that wo
componenttext: Well, a few comments there. I mean, the first thing is, no, we have not begun any qualification or integration-related activities for our products. And I think it's important that to note that we continue to operate as 2 separate companies. And so that would be inappropriate for us to be engaging of that kind of activity at this point. Now relative to the timing, let me make a few comments on that. From a financial perspective, when we talked about the financial synergies that we expected to realize, there was some timing that was wrapped around that. There's no changing -- there's no change in terms of expectations as it relates to that time. So that remains consistent. Obviously, we'll update the investment community as we move forward on how that timing may change, et cetera. But there are multiple considerations that we had to think about. Obviously, the most important thing is that we want to execute the transition in a way that makes the most sense for our partners. And from -- so that's our customers as well as our relationship with Intel. We've enjoyed a very strong relationship with Intel over a period of time, and we want to make sure that we're doing this in a way that makes the most sense for all of the parties involved. So that will take some time. And we do believe that when we talk about the financial synergies that we would realize that we factored in appropriately those time consideration in our thinking.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Wamsi Mohan of Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Wamsi Mohan of Merrill Lynch.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I know the acquisition has not closed yet [indiscernible] this acquisition. But how are you viewing the relative progress of the 3D NAND roadmap at SanDisk, especially in the context of other industry investments? And what time frame do you expect SanDisk
componenttext: I know the acquisition has not closed yet [indiscernible] this acquisition. But how are you viewing the relative progress of the 3D NAND roadmap at SanDisk, especially in the context of other industry investments? And what time frame do you expect SanDisk acquisition to be accretive given the moving pieces? And I have a follow-up.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So I'll speak to it in general because we don't have perfect visibility into that. But we continued to be encouraged, I mean, we did extensive due diligence just to kind of backup on where we believe that SanDisk was at from a 3D NAND transition pers
componenttext: Yes. So I'll speak to it in general because we don't have perfect visibility into that. But we continued to be encouraged, I mean, we did extensive due diligence just to kind of backup on where we believe that SanDisk was at from a 3D NAND transition perspective. And we have monitored their progress as time has gone on. And as you saw in their earnings release, they continue to make good progress. So we're actually very pleased with where they're at on their 3D NAND transition. We are not in a position to be updating our financial view on the transaction. I mean, the numbers that we put out there remain intact. And, obviously, there are a lot of moving parts or a lot of variables that can change. But in general, we continue to believe that the financial assumptions that we have looked at remains solid as it relates to the acquisition of SanDisk.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then a follow-up, could you talk about the potential to raise prices more broadly across the portfolio? And what impact on the flip side do you think that raising prices could have on the rate of SSD adoption? Did you see some [indiscernible] already?
componenttext: And then a follow-up, could you talk about the potential to raise prices more broadly across the portfolio? And what impact on the flip side do you think that raising prices could have on the rate of SSD adoption? Did you see some [indiscernible] already?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, the ability to raise prices, that's always a difficult question to answer. I mean, what we're trying to do is we're trying to provide value to our customers. And there's a lot of different ways you can provide value to the customers. And we have to
componenttext: Well, the ability to raise prices, that's always a difficult question to answer. I mean, what we're trying to do is we're trying to provide value to our customers. And there's a lot of different ways you can provide value to the customers. And we have to have price competitive products, but we also need to make sure that we've got sufficient returns on those products that we're selling that allows us to reinvest in our technology, in our products such that those products continue to remain compelling. And so as we indicated, we have taken some efforts and seen price increases stick in the 2.5-inch market. We saw steeper declines in the enterprise market. We chose not to participate on some of those areas. We're now in the process of instituting some selective price increases in the enterprise market, and it's too early to tell at this point to what extent they're going to stick. And so we'll have to see because there are other market participants and we are just trying to run our own place and see how it all works out.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Mark Moskowitz from Barclays.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Mark Moskowitz from Barclays.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I want to follow-up on the last question in terms of trying to understand what are your assumptions around the kind of the factor, if you will, in terms of HDD versus SSD penetration? How much of PCs, server and storage capacity currently are served by HD
componenttext: I want to follow-up on the last question in terms of trying to understand what are your assumptions around the kind of the factor, if you will, in terms of HDD versus SSD penetration? How much of PCs, server and storage capacity currently are served by HDD versus SSD? And what is the trend over the next 2, 3 years that gave you confidence to be one [indiscernible] 2 become this agnostic media provider?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And, Mike, we'll have Mike take a stab at that.
componenttext: And, Mike, we'll have Mike take a stab at that.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Think about a different way for each segments. In the case of PC, it's a unit replacement. So if you think about a PC, most often that's a single simple storage device and there's going to be a selection made between HD or an SSD. So the trends there rela
componenttext: Think about a different way for each segments. In the case of PC, it's a unit replacement. So if you think about a PC, most often that's a single simple storage device and there's going to be a selection made between HD or an SSD. So the trends there relative to SSD penetration, we've been tracking them for some time in the SSD versus PC outlook or [indiscernible] mid-30s[ph] in terms of penetration, that's continuing to track in a way that we've anticipated. So we don't see anything unusual there happening with that, although we do believe that trend will continue. Within the enterprise segment, it's a very different dynamic. It's really based on workload, it's based on where cost is driven on a cost per IO basis, flash becomes a more attractive option. I talked earlier about where the displacement is happening with performance enterprise, it's primarily in 2 spots. One is when you put it into an array form, so the traditional storage systems area and that's where you can get a more efficient cost per IO across that total infrastructure system infrastructure. So it's not really based upon a storage capacity metric, it's based on looking at the workloads, looking at where we need to optimize I/O versus storage. So it's a different set of calculus, it's not a 1 1 replacement, either, given these dynamics. So we do see that trend happening in a different way in the storage systems area. Moving into service, it follows something closer to the PC model where you have low-end and midrange servers that tend to have a number of storage devices and it tends to be price point related. So you match the CPUs, the memory and the storage performance in a way to deliver a price and value proposition. So that marketplace will more closely follow the way the PC marketplace is going. And frankly, it will go at a slower trajectory. So we don't see that kind of impact in the server marketplace relative to SSD replacement that we see in the storage systems market.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think just to kind of add to that, it's a little bit of kind of a financial overlay to it. I mean, the trends that we're seeing are consistent with our expectations, I think that's an important thing. But as you know, sometimes the difficult thing
componenttext: Yes. I think just to kind of add to that, it's a little bit of kind of a financial overlay to it. I mean, the trends that we're seeing are consistent with our expectations, I think that's an important thing. But as you know, sometimes the difficult thing is not so much to predict what the trend is going to be, but the rate and pace. And so the rate and pace is kind of difficult to estimate. But what's important relative to what we're doing and it really speaks to the importance of having this integration opportunity as it relates to WD and HGST as well as the acquisition of SanDisk is that you have the optionality or ability to maneuver around the rate and pace issue that sometimes present themselves to, for example, take cost out faster than you need to a legacy businesses and also shift over to newer technologies quicker. And so with the changes that we're making and the options that we have, we'll be able to modulate not only those trends but the rate and pace issue, which is more difficult to predict as we move forward. So we think it's very important to recognize that in terms of our ability to be able to do with those changes.

componenttext: Yes. Well, it's difficult to predict at this point, to be honest. Because we got a weak macroeconomic environment. componenttext: Well, there's 2 factors, to consider. One is that we have these cost savings that we'll be realizing as a consequence of the WD, HGST integration, which will, obviously, assist us in improving our gross margins. The other thing, which Mike talked about, is over the last really 3 quarters, ourselves and as an industry, have been dealing with a bit of a suppressed demand environment in the capacity enterprise market. And so as that works its way back up to a more normalized demand environment, say, starting in the second half of this year, which is back on that 35% kind of exabyte consumption model, that will aid us from of us margin perspective. And then additionally, as I mentioned earlier, we have taken some actions to selectively increase our prices, which we also believe assuming that they stick, will provide a benefit to our gross margins.

componenttext:
Good afternoon, and I thank you for standing by. Welcome to Western Digital's financial results for the third quarter fiscal year 2016. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this call is being recorded.
Now I will turn the call over to Mr. Bob Blair. You may begin.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you. This conference call contains forward-looking statements within the meaning of the federal securities laws. Such forward-looking statements are based upon management's current expectations and include known and unknown risks, uncertainties and
componenttext:
Thank you. This conference call contains forward-looking statements within the meaning of the federal securities laws. Such forward-looking statements are based upon management's current expectations and include known and unknown risks, uncertainties and other factors, many of which Western Digital is unable to predict or control, that may cause Western Digital's actual results, performance or plans to differ materially from those expressed or implied by such forward-looking statements.
This call does not constitute an offer to purchase or a solicitation of an offer to sell any securities or a solicitation of any vote or approval in connection with the pending acquisition with SanDisk. Western Digital filed a Form S-4 registration statement with the SEC, which was declared effective by the SEC on February 5, 2016. And Western Digital filed the definitive proxy statement/prospectus on February 5, 2016, which was mailed to Western Digital and SanDisk stockholders on our about that date. Investors and shareholders should read the joint proxy statement/prospectus carefully because it contains important information about the acquisition.
Further, references will be made during this call to non-GAAP financial measures. Reconciliations of the differences between the non-GAAP measures we provide during this call to the comparable GAAP financial measures are included in the quarterly fact sheet posted in the Investor section of our website. The information provided during this call regarding the savings we expect to realize as a result of the integration of our WD and HGST subsidiaries and the expected cost to achieve such savings will also be included in the quarterly fact sheet posted in the Investor Relations section of our website. [Operator Instructions] I also want note that copies of remarks from today's call will be available on the IR section of our website following the conclusion of this call.
And I will now turn the call over to Chief Executive Officer, Steve Milligan.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us. With me today are Mike Cordano, our President and Chief Operating Officer; and Olivier Leonetti, our Chief Financial Officer. After my opening remarks, Olivier will give additional commentary on our March quar
componenttext:
Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us. With me today are Mike Cordano, our President and Chief Operating Officer; and Olivier Leonetti, our Chief Financial Officer. After my opening remarks, Olivier will give additional commentary on our March quarter performance and our outlook for the June quarter. He will also provide an update on savings associated with the integration of our HGST and WD subsidiaries.
I am pleased to report that our plan to close the SanDisk acquisition in the June quarter is on track, having received shareholder approval in March and having obtained the committed debt financing associated with the transaction earlier this month. We continue to work constructively with China's Ministry of Commerce on its review of the acquisition, the last remaining regulatory approval required to close the SanDisk acquisition. Subject to gaining MOFCOM approval and closing the acquisition shortly thereafter, we plan to provide the investment community with an update to the stand-alone guidance we are providing today to reflect the partial period of ownership of the SanDisk business in the June quarter.
Aggregate demand for hard drives in the March quarter was generally consistent with our expectations. We anticipate that hard drive demand in the June quarter will be slightly down from the March quarter given continued, softer PC demand and weaker-than-expected demand in performance enterprise. We believe we have the ability to increase our gross margins sequentially in the June quarter by continuing to take cost out of the business through our ongoing and unique integration activities of the HGST and WD subsidiaries and through our focus on optimizing our market position and product portfolio mix.
We continue to manage our business effectively in a dynamic storage demand environment. Computer usage continues to shift from PCs to mobile devices. Storage technologies and PCs continue to evolve, and enterprise workloads are moving increasingly to cloud-based architectures. It's worth noting that as companies evaluate the shift to cloud computing, they're carefully managing their IT spending, affecting both client and enterprise-related purchases in the near term. 
In the meantime, the creation of data and the amount of it being stored continues to grow, underpinning a promising, long-term growth opportunity in the storage industry. Our strategy, to become a broad-based provider of media-agnostic storage solutions, anticipates these and other trends. After we complete the acquisition of SanDisk, we will be better positioned to address and capitalize on these changes and opportunities with the industry's broadest set of storage solutions, a rich technology portfolio and an experienced team in both rotating magnetic and nonvolatile memory.
Olivier will now provide details on our third quarter performance and outlook for the June quarter.
Olivier?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Steve. Our revenue for the March quarter was $2.8 billion. We shipped a total of 43.1 million hard drives at an average selling price of $60. Our non-GAAP gross margin was 28.1% and operating expenses totaled $477 million. Non-GAAP tax expense
componenttext:
Thank you, Steve. Our revenue for the March quarter was $2.8 billion. We shipped a total of 43.1 million hard drives at an average selling price of $60. Our non-GAAP gross margin was 28.1% and operating expenses totaled $477 million. Non-GAAP tax expense for the March quarter was $26 million or 8% of non-GAAP pretax income. On a non-GAAP basis, net income was $283 million or $1.21 per share.
In the March quarter, we generated $485 million in cash from operations and our free cash flow totaled $352 million. Our CapEx totaled $133 million or 5% of revenue. We also declared a dividend in the amount of $0.50 per share. We closed the quarter with total cash and cash equivalents of $5.9 billion, of which approximately $400 million was held in the U.S.
I will now provide an update on cost-savings initiative as a result of the integration of our WD and HGST subsidiaries. This information is also provided in our quarterly fact sheet posted on our website. All my references in the following commentary are based on calendar years. As a reminder, we provided our initial estimate of these savings on our last earnings conference call in late January.
Based on our ongoing integration activity, we are revising our associated savings and cost estimates. We now expect to achieve total savings of $800 million on an annualized run rate basis by the end of 2017 versus the $650 million estimated previously. Specifically, savings from operating expenses are now expected to be $450 million on an annualized run rate basis, of which 2/3 will occur by the end of 2016 and the balance by the end of 2017. This would result in a new OpEx run rate of $460 million per quarter exiting 2017. This compares with our earlier estimate of $400 million OpEx savings with 50-50 split between the 2 years and a run rate of $470 million per quarter exiting 2017.
For cost of goods sold, we now expect to achieve $350 million of savings on an annualized run rate basis, of which 50% will occur by the end of 2016 and the balance by the end of 2017. This compares with our earlier estimate of $250 million of annualized run rate savings by the end of 2017, with a 50-50 split between the 2 years. As a reminder, these savings will provide us with the opportunity to consistently operate in the top half of our existing gross margin model of 27% to 32%. 
We continue to estimate cash expense to achieve these savings to be approximately $800 million. We now expect 60% of these expenses to be incurred in 2016 and the balance in 2017. This timing compares with our earlier estimate of 75% being incurred in 2016 and the balance in 2017.
Moving on to our guidance for the June quarter. We expect revenue to be in a range of $2.6 billion to $2.7 billion. On a non-GAAP basis, we expect gross margin percentage to be up from our March quarter, operating expenses of approximately $475 million. Excluding the impact due to the interest expense from debt financing related to the SanDisk acquisition, we estimate non-GAAP earnings per share between $1 and $1.10. As Steve mentioned, we look forward to providing you with an update of today's stand-alone guidance to reflect the anticipated partial period of ownership of SanDisk in the June quarter.
Operator, we are now ready to open the call for questions.

componenttext: Basically, Sherri, we're basically eliminating redundancies, where we've got redundant functions between the 2 entities. And also, just why has the number changed? componenttext: Yes. And Sherri, just to clarify, the EPS estimate that we provided does not include the impact of interest expense associated with the acquisition. That'll be a full-on view for calendar Q2.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: A few questions. If you could just talk first, Steve, you did start to touch on the weakness in PCs and enterprise. But if you could just elaborate on both the demand and pricing trends by category? And then I have a follow-up.
componenttext: A few questions. If you could just talk first, Steve, you did start to touch on the weakness in PCs and enterprise. But if you could just elaborate on both the demand and pricing trends by category? And then I have a follow-up.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. I'll comment on it, and then Mike Cordano may want to add a little bit as well as we go through. From a demand perspective, as I indicated, from an aggregate-demand perspective, things came in pretty much the way that we had expected, right? We had
componenttext: Sure. I'll comment on it, and then Mike Cordano may want to add a little bit as well as we go through. From a demand perspective, as I indicated, from an aggregate-demand perspective, things came in pretty much the way that we had expected, right? We had called a 100 million-unit TAM and came in at, whatever, 99.8 million. That's our estimate, right? We haven't seen Toshiba's numbers yet. And within that, I would say that the PC market obviously, remains weak and a bit weaker than what we expected. Now that being said, I'm going to sound like I'm contradicting myself, we had hedged that a little bit because we've been pretty bearish on the PC market for a while. But clearly, the PC market remains a bit weaker than what we expected. I would say that from a demand perspective that the area of, if you want to it biggest surprise, was that performance enterprise was weaker than we expected. Mike can comment a little bit on what we're seeing thereafter I kind of give a view on what we saw from a pricing perspective. And then there were some other areas that were, maybe, kind of slightly better than what we expected, where in aggregate, it came out to kind of 100 million-unit TAM number. Now from a pricing perspective, kind of a mixed bag there. On the positive side, we were able to increase our pricing in the 2.5-inch market, both oriented towards notebook as well as in gaming. So we were able to increase our prices, and those price increases have stuck and are reflected in our go-forward estimates as it relates to our financials. On the negative side is that we saw steeper-than-anticipated price declines in the enterprise market, both in performance enterprise and even more specifically, in capacity enterprise and to be even more specific on that, in the 4, 8 terabyte capacity points. And you can see that if you look at our margins, where they were short of our expectations and we were down quarter-on-quarter, that is directly correlated to what we saw from a pricing perspective. And by the way, further to that, we actually lost share in the enterprise market as we chose not to participate in some of those more steeper declines from a pricing perspective. Now what we're doing as a consequence to that is that we're taking the action from our standpoint, because we want to make sure that we've got sufficient dollars to reinvest back into our business to continue to innovate and provide compelling products for our customers, we are making selective price increases in certain enterprise markets. And at this point, we're not sure if they're going to stick, but we're certainly hoping that they do. And with that, I'll ask Mike to comment a bit on performance enterprise demand dynamics.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Rich, so I think it's important to start to delineating the performance enterprise marketplace. And if you think about it as those performance enterprise drives that sell into the storage system marketplaces versus the server marketplace, what we hav
componenttext: Yes, Rich, so I think it's important to start to delineating the performance enterprise marketplace. And if you think about it as those performance enterprise drives that sell into the storage system marketplaces versus the server marketplace, what we have seen for some time is the decline in 15,000 RPM. That continues. That trend down continues. We are now seeing some more trending down happening in the 10k market quarter-over-quarter. But the pronounced reduction we see is really in the storage segment of the marketplace. I think that's reflected in what we see people doing with all-flash arrays and whatnot. So going forward, we think we'll see accelerating trend, downward trends within the storage segment, but a more stable profile within the server segment. And we'll be, as Steve said, looking at the way that portfolio shapes up and positioning ourselves appropriately.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And then lastly, Olivier, I know it's early. But in light of recent actions by the Treasury Department on initially, I guess, tax inversions, but it could potentially have broader impacts on just broad cross-border transfers and othe
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And then lastly, Olivier, I know it's early. But in light of recent actions by the Treasury Department on initially, I guess, tax inversions, but it could potentially have broader impacts on just broad cross-border transfers and other things. Do you see any impact at this point on the way you wanted to normalize the tax rate between the 2 companies over time?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Rich, obviously, this recent notice is a draft, which is currently being opened for comments. And while it's premature for us to provide more details at this stage, we feel comfortable with the structure of our transaction. So no change at this stage,
componenttext: So Rich, obviously, this recent notice is a draft, which is currently being opened for comments. And while it's premature for us to provide more details at this stage, we feel comfortable with the structure of our transaction. So no change at this stage, Rich.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Aaron Rakers with Stifel, Nicolaus.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Aaron Rakers with Stifel, Nicolaus.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Couple of questions also, if I can. First of all, as we look at the capacity shipment growth for the industry, it's continued to be relatively slow. I was curious if you could help us understand or delineate between what you've seen capacity shipment grow
componenttext: Couple of questions also, if I can. First of all, as we look at the capacity shipment growth for the industry, it's continued to be relatively slow. I was curious if you could help us understand or delineate between what you've seen capacity shipment growth wise in the PC market as well as CE and then relative to the overall enterprise market. And then, in the context of the pricing environment, I'm curious of how you would frame the discussion around the gross margin differential between those segments.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Let me touch on that capacity growth. So we continue to see -- again, looking on an annualized basis, considering the calendar year, capacity enterprise continues to trend at this 35% run rate. Last year, it looks like -- and the data is preliminary
componenttext: Okay. Let me touch on that capacity growth. So we continue to see -- again, looking on an annualized basis, considering the calendar year, capacity enterprise continues to trend at this 35% run rate. Last year, it looks like -- and the data is preliminary that it came in around 34%. We would expect this year also to be tracking to that number, maybe slightly greater. We'll see how the year pans out. Now the one thing I should point out, we discussed this last time, is calendar year '15 was inverted relative to seasonality: stronger in the first half, weaker in the second. This year is more traditional seasonality, where we expect strength in the back end of the year, and that's further supported by, what, a number of the hyperscale companies have talked about relative to expected CapEx. So that growth remains as expected. The softness and capacity shipments really is across the other markets, led by the PC market as well as this new news that we discussed today on performance enterprise.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And any comments on the relative margin differential between the segments?
componenttext: Okay. And any comments on the relative margin differential between the segments?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Aaron, I'm not sure there's any new commentary. I mean, obviously, the higher-margin segments for us and -- is in the enterprise area, I mean in capacity enterprise and performance. And then, although still attractive margins, the low end of that would be
componenttext: Aaron, I'm not sure there's any new commentary. I mean, obviously, the higher-margin segments for us and -- is in the enterprise area, I mean in capacity enterprise and performance. And then, although still attractive margins, the low end of that would be client-related activity as well as in gaming. And so there's really no change in terms of our margin hierarchy that we've talked about previously.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Amit Daryanani with RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Amit Daryanani with RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I have a question and a follow-up as well. If we could just start with for the June quarter, you guys, I think, are looking at the TAM or [indiscernible] revenues declined by about 6%. Is that entirely going to come from units? Is there a pricing dynamic
componenttext: I have a question and a follow-up as well. If we could just start with for the June quarter, you guys, I think, are looking at the TAM or [indiscernible] revenues declined by about 6%. Is that entirely going to come from units? Is there a pricing dynamic as well? And any segment information you could provide in terms of what's going -- getting incrementally softer in June would be helpful.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so -- and you look at -- so we would say that the TAM, to be more specific, will be about 95 million units for the June quarter. And the primary reason for that is continued weakness in terms of the PC market, and not only that, but frankly, from our
componenttext: Yes, so -- and you look at -- so we would say that the TAM, to be more specific, will be about 95 million units for the June quarter. And the primary reason for that is continued weakness in terms of the PC market, and not only that, but frankly, from our standpoint and as well as our customers, a very cautious view with regards to that market. Not a lot of bullish views out there on the PC market as well as continued softness in terms of the performance enterprise. Those are the only ones that I think are really kind of worthy of calling out. We've got some other puts and takes in terms of normal seasonal trends that we see from Q1 to Q2. But the primary reason for that decline is really those 2 factors that I called out. The other thing that I would add to that is that if you go back to our prior conference call, we had anticipated that the March quarter would be the low point of the year from a TAM perspective. Obviously, that didn't -- that had not borne itself out, assuming that TAM turns out to be in 95 million. And the primary reason for that is, again, because of weaker PC sales and softer demand for performance, for traditional performance enterprise hard drives.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Perfect. Now -- and if I just follow up on the enterprise SSD side, revenues are down, I think, 11% year-over-year. I you had talked about it being down last quarter somewhat, but seems a little bit more severe than I would have thought and what some of y
componenttext: Perfect. Now -- and if I just follow up on the enterprise SSD side, revenues are down, I think, 11% year-over-year. I you had talked about it being down last quarter somewhat, but seems a little bit more severe than I would have thought and what some of your peers have been talking about. So I'm just wondering, could you just talk about what's happening within that segment? And how do you see that transpire for the rest of the year?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think we talked about a product transition underway. Certainly, we are seeing increased competitiveness there. But for us, we're in the midst of a product transition, which we'll be through as we -- we will get through as we progress through the ye
componenttext: Yes. I think we talked about a product transition underway. Certainly, we are seeing increased competitiveness there. But for us, we're in the midst of a product transition, which we'll be through as we -- we will get through as we progress through the year. So that largely accounts for the difference you're talking about.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, and by the way, just kind of give you some insight to that. We had obviously expected, and we messaged and sort of telegraphed a decrease in terms of that revenue. And the decrease was more or less consistent with what we expected. And not only that,
componenttext: Yes, and by the way, just kind of give you some insight to that. We had obviously expected, and we messaged and sort of telegraphed a decrease in terms of that revenue. And the decrease was more or less consistent with what we expected. And not only that, we probably were -- we did a little bit better than we thought. So it's not concerning for us, it's something that we expected. And it just has to do with the normal product transition that we're working through on our end with our customers.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. And I'll add a little more color. I think relative to strategic engagements, they remain very well intact, and we think we'll get through this in sort of the normal course of things. So no ongoing impact that we would expect once we get through the
componenttext: Right. And I'll add a little more color. I think relative to strategic engagements, they remain very well intact, and we think we'll get through this in sort of the normal course of things. So no ongoing impact that we would expect once we get through the transition.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Mehdi Hosseini with Susquehanna.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Mehdi Hosseini with Susquehanna.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Steve, it seems like the characterization of your customer and trend in their buying behavior is changing. The traditional enterprises haven't been attractive over the past few years and that has been replaced by the cloud guys, and the cloud guys are pus
componenttext: Steve, it seems like the characterization of your customer and trend in their buying behavior is changing. The traditional enterprises haven't been attractive over the past few years and that has been replaced by the cloud guys, and the cloud guys are pushing for more of array procurement. In that context, do you see the change in your customer characterization having an impact in how you define different segments of the market?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Go ahead, Mike.
componenttext: Go ahead, Mike.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so I think we absolutely see a transition between our customers, but that's really reflected mostly by moving from platform to traditional client/server markets to cloud-based architectures, as we talked about in the prepared remarks. So that archite
componenttext: Yes, so I think we absolutely see a transition between our customers, but that's really reflected mostly by moving from platform to traditional client/server markets to cloud-based architectures, as we talked about in the prepared remarks. So that architectural shift is happening and with that, the ratio of business is trending towards more of the cloud-based architecture when we talk about enterprise. So as we look at the customers, certainly, is that the relative revenue is changing. The way we look at them, engage them is also changing, and that's all contemplated within our business and our modeling going forward. So yes, to your question in both from a customer transition as well as a -- which architectures are we shipping into and how workloads are migrating.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Which makes it lumpier? And the follow-up has to do with demand. Have you already started the kind of qualification as you go through the integration of SanDisk? And how should we think about the timing associated? Because as you go through the qualificat
componenttext: Which makes it lumpier? And the follow-up has to do with demand. Have you already started the kind of qualification as you go through the integration of SanDisk? And how should we think about the timing associated? Because as you go through the qualification for your own -- for the existing SSD products as well as consolidating enterprise SSDs once SanDisk is integrated, I imagine there would be a time or a lagging effect how you get your arms around it. Is that going to -- do we need to wait till July conference call to get more clarification? Or how should we think about this timing? Any color you can provide will be appreciated.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, a few comments there. I mean, the first thing is, no, we have not begun any qualification or integration-related activities for our products. And I think it's important that to note that, obviously, we continue to operate as 2 separate companies. An
componenttext: Well, a few comments there. I mean, the first thing is, no, we have not begun any qualification or integration-related activities for our products. And I think it's important that to note that, obviously, we continue to operate as 2 separate companies. And so that would be inappropriate for us to be engaging in that kind of activity at this point. Now relative to the timing, let me make a few comments on that. From a financial perspective, when we talked about the financial synergies that we expected to realize, there was some timing that was wrapped around that. There's no changing -- there's no change in terms of the expectation as it relates to that timing, so that remains consistent. Obviously, we'll update the investment community as we move forward on how that timing may change, et cetera. But there are multiple considerations that we have to think about. Obviously, the most important thing is that we want to execute the transition in a way that makes the most sense for our partners. And from -- so that's our customers as well as our relationship with Intel. We've enjoyed a very strong relationship with Intel over a period of time, and we want to make sure that we're doing this in a way that makes the most sense for all of the parties involved. So that will take some time, and we do believe that when we talk about the financial synergies that we would realize, that we factored in appropriately those time considerations in our thinking.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Wamsi Mohan with Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Wamsi Mohan with Merrill Lynch.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I know the acquisition has not closed yet, the SanDisk acquisition, but how are you viewing the relative progress of the 3D NAND road map at SanDisk, especially in the context of other industry investments? And what time frame do you expect the SanDisk ac
componenttext: I know the acquisition has not closed yet, the SanDisk acquisition, but how are you viewing the relative progress of the 3D NAND road map at SanDisk, especially in the context of other industry investments? And what time frame do you expect the SanDisk acquisition to be accretive given the moving pieces? And I have a follow-up.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so I'm going to speak to it in general because we don't have perfect visibility into that. But we continue to be encouraged. I mean, obviously, we did extensive due diligence to kind of back up on where we believe that SanDisk was at from a 3D NAND t
componenttext: Yes, so I'm going to speak to it in general because we don't have perfect visibility into that. But we continue to be encouraged. I mean, obviously, we did extensive due diligence to kind of back up on where we believe that SanDisk was at from a 3D NAND transition perspective. And we have monitored their progress as time has gone on, and as you saw in their earnings release, they continue to make good progress. So we're actually very pleased with where they're at on their 3D NAND transition. We are not in a position to be updating our financial view on the transaction. I mean, the numbers that we put out there remain intact and obviously, there are a lot of moving parts or a lot of variables that can change. But in general, we continue to believe that the financial assumptions that we have looked at remains solid as it relates to the acquisition of SanDisk.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Steve, and as follow up, could you talk about the potential to raise prices more broadly across the portfolio? And what impact on the flip side do you think that raising prices could have on the rate of SSD adoption? Did you see some of that already?
componenttext: Steve, and as follow up, could you talk about the potential to raise prices more broadly across the portfolio? And what impact on the flip side do you think that raising prices could have on the rate of SSD adoption? Did you see some of that already?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I mean, the ability to raise prices, that's always a difficult question to answer. I mean, what we're trying to do is we're trying to provide value to our customers. And there's a lot of different ways you can provide value to the customers. And we
componenttext: Well, I mean, the ability to raise prices, that's always a difficult question to answer. I mean, what we're trying to do is we're trying to provide value to our customers. And there's a lot of different ways you can provide value to the customers. And we have to have price-competitive products, but we also need to make sure that we've got sufficient returns on those products that we're selling that allows us to reinvest in our technology and in our products such that those products continue to remain compelling. And so as we indicated, we have taken some efforts and seen price increases stick in the 2.5-inch market. We saw steeper declines in the enterprise market. We chose not to participate on some of those areas. We're now in the process of instituting some selective price increases in the enterprise market, and it's too early to tell at this point to what extent they're going to stick. And so we'll have to see because there are other market participants, and we're just trying to run our own plays and see how it all works out.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Mark Moskowitz with Barclays.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Mark Moskowitz with Barclays.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I want to go off on the last question in terms of just trying to understand what have been your assumptions around the kind of the vector, if you will, in terms of HDD versus SSD penetration in terms of how much of PCs server and storage capacity currentl
componenttext: I want to go off on the last question in terms of just trying to understand what have been your assumptions around the kind of the vector, if you will, in terms of HDD versus SSD penetration in terms of how much of PCs server and storage capacity currently is served by HDD versus SSD? And where does that kind of trend over at least 2, 3 years that gave you confidence to be, one, pursuing demand; does it also -- two, to become this agnostic media provider?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mark, I'll have Mike take a stab at that.
componenttext: Mark, I'll have Mike take a stab at that.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: You need to think about it differently for each segment. In the case of PC, it's a unit replacement. So if you think about a PC, it has -- most often, it has a single storage device, and there's going to be a selection made between a HDD or an SSD. So the
componenttext: You need to think about it differently for each segment. In the case of PC, it's a unit replacement. So if you think about a PC, it has -- most often, it has a single storage device, and there's going to be a selection made between a HDD or an SSD. So the trends there relative to SSD penetration, we've been tracking them for some time. In the SSD versus PC outlook, we're in the mid-30s in terms of penetration. That's continuing to track in a way that we've anticipated. So we don't see anything unusual there happening with that, although we do believe the trend will continue. Within the enterprise segment, it's a very different dynamic. It's really based on workload and it's based on where cost is driven on a cost per I/O basis. Flash becomes a more attractive option. I talked earlier about where the displacement is happening with performance enterprise. It's primarily in 2 spots: One is when you put it into an array form, so the traditional storage system area, and that's where you can get a more efficient cost per I/O across total infrastructure system infrastructure. So it's not really based upon a storage capacity metric. It's based on looking at the workloads, looking at where we need to optimize I/O versus storage. So it's a different set of calculus. It's not a 1 for 1 replacement either, given these dynamics. So we do see that trend happening in a different way in the storage systems area. Moving into servers, it follows something closer to the PC model, where you have low-end and midrange servers that tend to have a number of storage devices, and it tends to be price point related. So you match the CPU, the memory and the storage performance in a way to deliver a price and value proposition. So that marketplace will more closely follow the way the PC marketplace is going. And frankly, it will go at a slower trajectory. So we don't see the kind of impact in the server marketplace relative to SSD replacement that we see in the storage systems market.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, and I think, Mark, just to kind of add to that. I mean, it's a little bit of kind of a financial overlay to it. I mean, the trends that we're seeing are consistent with our expectations, I think that's an important thing. But as you know, sometimes t
componenttext: Yes, and I think, Mark, just to kind of add to that. I mean, it's a little bit of kind of a financial overlay to it. I mean, the trends that we're seeing are consistent with our expectations, I think that's an important thing. But as you know, sometimes the difficult thing is not so much to predict what the trend is going to be but the rate and pace. And so the rate and pace is kind of difficult to estimate. But what's important relative to what we're doing, and it really speaks to the importance of having this integration opportunity as it relates to WD and HGST as well as with the acquisition of SanDisk, is that you have the optionality or the ability to maneuver around the rate and pace issues that sometimes present themselves to, for example, take cost out faster than you need to in legacy businesses and also shift over to newer technologies quicker. And so with the changes that we're making and the options that we have, we'll be able to modulate, not only those trends, but the rate and pace issue, which is more difficult to predict as we move forward. So we think it's very important to recognize that in terms of our ability to be able to deal with those changes.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, and one last comment, just to sort of defend what Steve said. So although the pieces underneath are moving around on us, as we've described, the aggregate spend in enterprise on storage, when you combine SSD and HDD, continues to grow at a rate that'
componenttext: Yes, and one last comment, just to sort of defend what Steve said. So although the pieces underneath are moving around on us, as we've described, the aggregate spend in enterprise on storage, when you combine SSD and HDD, continues to grow at a rate that's consistent with our expectation.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, I appreciate that. It sounds like it's a pretty frenetic environment. But it sounds like, at this point, you will be in position to optimize the combined company and not have to be playing catch up relative to some of these dynamics. I guess I have
componenttext: Okay, I appreciate that. It sounds like it's a pretty frenetic environment. But it sounds like, at this point, you will be in position to optimize the combined company and not have to be playing catch up relative to some of these dynamics. I guess I have just one follow-up though, if I could. Are you seeing any difference in terms of the cloud providers versus the on-premise? Are they acting a little differently with respect to flash versus disk?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, so the cloud guys have been on a capacity enterprise plus flash model for some time. They have not been a big consumer of performance enterprise. That really goes to our sort of legacy systems businesses. So that continues -- that trend continues with
componenttext: No, so the cloud guys have been on a capacity enterprise plus flash model for some time. They have not been a big consumer of performance enterprise. That really goes to our sort of legacy systems businesses. So that continues -- that trend continues within the cloud world.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from James Kisner with Jefferies.
componenttext: Our next question comes from James Kisner with Jefferies.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I just want to clarify your comments on MOFCOM. So there was a news service reporting that the NDRC is getting involved in that MOFCOM approval process, seen some complaints from [indiscernible] suppliers around the steel. And just wondered if you can
componenttext: So I just want to clarify your comments on MOFCOM. So there was a news service reporting that the NDRC is getting involved in that MOFCOM approval process, seen some complaints from [indiscernible] suppliers around the steel. And just wondered if you can comment whether they're these complaints and has that slowed the approval process at all. And when do think you might get approval?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, yes, I mean, so just as I said, I mean, we have a very strong relationship with MOFCOM. We have a very constructive dialogue with them. I'm not going to comment and chase rumors around. But I'm very pleased with the progress that we're making, and w
componenttext: Well, yes, I mean, so just as I said, I mean, we have a very strong relationship with MOFCOM. We have a very constructive dialogue with them. I'm not going to comment and chase rumors around. But I'm very pleased with the progress that we're making, and we expect to close the transaction here in the second quarter. So no issues from that perspective.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So just as a follow-up. This quarter, I think you spent less in CapEx in absolute terms than you have in a very long time. And so wondering how we should think about the capital intensity of Western Digital's business sort of ex SanDisk going forwar
componenttext: Okay. So just as a follow-up. This quarter, I think you spent less in CapEx in absolute terms than you have in a very long time. And so wondering how we should think about the capital intensity of Western Digital's business sort of ex SanDisk going forward the next few quarters as well as the next couple of years.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Obviously, as we are rationalizing the footprint of our organization, that will have an impact on CapEx. Obviously, we're looking at maximizing the use of cash. To answer specifically to your question, 4% of revenue going forward is probably -- as CapEx,
componenttext: Obviously, as we are rationalizing the footprint of our organization, that will have an impact on CapEx. Obviously, we're looking at maximizing the use of cash. To answer specifically to your question, 4% of revenue going forward is probably -- as CapEx, probably be a good number to use.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Ananda Baruah with Brean Capital.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Ananda Baruah with Brean Capital.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, 2 if I could. The first one, Steve, is just to sort of follow on your comment about rate and pace. How do you guys, I guess, philosophically think about the interplay in the enterprise between what's going on with flash and then sort of the tradi
componenttext: I guess, 2 if I could. The first one, Steve, is just to sort of follow on your comment about rate and pace. How do you guys, I guess, philosophically think about the interplay in the enterprise between what's going on with flash and then sort of the traditional enterprise portfolio? And I know you can't comment sort of probably specifically about the SanDisk product, but just from what attracted you in that regard to their portfolio, just a bigger picture. Did you see the shift maybe taking place a little bit more quickly, the enterprise to flash, from sort of from performance to HDD? Do you think that there can be a relatively, I guess, smooth transition from a revenue dollar perspective relative to the WD P&L? It seems like it was -- I think you're implying it was a little bit more disruptive this quarter than you thought it might have been. And so would love to get your thoughts on, at least at a high level, how we might think about that interplay as we go forward. And then I had just one quick follow-up.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, let me try to answer that. So I think relative to a post-acquisition close situation, we will be able to participate in all segments of the enterprise SSD marketplace. So once we've accomplished that, the comment I made earlier relative to the growth
componenttext: Yes, let me try to answer that. So I think relative to a post-acquisition close situation, we will be able to participate in all segments of the enterprise SSD marketplace. So once we've accomplished that, the comment I made earlier relative to the growth within enterprise devices, SSD plus HDD being largely as expected, really the movement within. So we need to -- we really need the broad portfolio to do that. We are obviously excited to get to the point where we have that. So we think we have the diverse tools we need to manage that transition.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, and we were -- by the way, I mean, we were very pleased with the enterprise SSD numbers that SanDisk posted yesterday. So that's encouraging as well.
componenttext: Yes, and we were -- by the way, I mean, we were very pleased with the enterprise SSD numbers that SanDisk posted yesterday. So that's encouraging as well.

And frankly, I'm going to have to kind of skirt that question because I think it's still a little bit too far out to be able to predict that. But we would expect to see some sort of seasonal increase in demand in calendar Q3 and Q4. To where we should have a TAM, I mean, this is not going to really help you, but we clearly should have TAM that will be in excess of $400 million, right?
