componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Mehdi Hosseini with Susquehanna.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Actually, it's not Mehdi. It's David Ryzhik for Mehdi Hosseini on the line. Can you guys talk about your HDD capacity in terms of units and/or exabytes and what you've done in that regard and how that trends over the next quarters and in that context
componenttext: Yes. Actually, it's not Mehdi. It's David Ryzhik for Mehdi Hosseini on the line. Can you guys talk about your HDD capacity in terms of units and/or exabytes and what you've done in that regard and how that trends over the next quarters and in that context, how we can think about capacity utilization? And I have a follow-up.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So this is Steve. I'll take that. So I would say that --  I mean, there's a lot of dynamics that are going on in terms of our hard drive capacity because, as you know, over the last kind of several years, we've been going through a manufacturing rati
componenttext: Yes. So this is Steve. I'll take that. So I would say that --  I mean, there's a lot of dynamics that are going on in terms of our hard drive capacity because, as you know, over the last kind of several years, we've been going through a manufacturing rationalization process given declines that we've seen in the hard drive market. So there are kind of different puts and takes when you look at various different products or various different factory locations. But on balance right now in terms of hard drive manufacturing, I would say that we are kind of reasonably balanced. In other words, we're able to largely meet overall customer demand. And again, we are going to continue to rationalize this as we move forward. The one thing that we're a little bit cautious about and keeping our eye on is that, obviously, when you're talking about capacity enterprise products, which, as Mike indicated, the demand for there has been -- in that space has been reasonably robust. And that uses a lot of heads and disks because of the flatter count. And that has -- we have less flexibility both in terms of lead time and capacity in terms of heads and disks. And so as we look at that and as we watch and work closely with our customers, if, for one reason or another, we were to see, call it, a spike from a demand perspective, our ability to meet some of that upside might be more limited. So that's one thing that we're a bit cautious about right now. But overall, we feel pretty good about where we're at from a utilization and capacity perspective on the HDD front.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And as a follow-up for Mark, how can we think about the cash conversion cycle and more broadly speaking, like a normalized free cash flow rate as you've gotten your arms around the balance sheet and cash generation capability? Just any insight on how we c
componenttext: And as a follow-up for Mark, how can we think about the cash conversion cycle and more broadly speaking, like a normalized free cash flow rate as you've gotten your arms around the balance sheet and cash generation capability? Just any insight on how we can model that going forward?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So from a cash conversion cycle standpoint, I think you can model basically where we've been over the last couple of quarters, but you'll have some changing dynamics. So what I would expect is inventory will likely trend up, and this is really a fun
componenttext: Sure. So from a cash conversion cycle standpoint, I think you can model basically where we've been over the last couple of quarters, but you'll have some changing dynamics. So what I would expect is inventory will likely trend up, and this is really a function of us building strategic reserves as we restructure parts of our supply chain. And then eventually, you'll see the NAND parts of our business -- the allocation will begin to soften and we'll begin to build more inventory. So that will trend upwards a little bit. But you'll then, I think, see payables be extended from where they were in Q1. So I think, overall, you'll see a cash conversion cycle in about the range that it's been. And in terms of the cash flow generation margin, we're actually going to have a little bit more noise in that equation for the next few quarters primarily as a function of our restructurings and ongoing integration activities. But one of the things we will be doing during Investor Day is providing more visibility into the dynamics of that as well as a way to think about our long-term financial model and the key metrics around cash flow generation.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Amit Daryanani with RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Amit Daryanani with RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Jeriel Ong on behalf of Amit. Just have a few questions here. Number one, can you just touch on what drove the gross margin upside? I think it was up about 60 basis points versus your pre -- positive pre and 160 basis points versus initial guide.
componenttext: This is Jeriel Ong on behalf of Amit. Just have a few questions here. Number one, can you just touch on what drove the gross margin upside? I think it was up about 60 basis points versus your pre -- positive pre and 160 basis points versus initial guide. Was this more HDD or NAND or cost integration? And some rank order would be valuable.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I think, as we mentioned, the favorable pricing was across both parts of our business but primarily in the NAND area. And we did experience some additional benefits from mix, especially given the fact that we had the first full quarter of the flash pro
componenttext: So I think, as we mentioned, the favorable pricing was across both parts of our business but primarily in the NAND area. And we did experience some additional benefits from mix, especially given the fact that we had the first full quarter of the flash product revenue.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. And also, the strong performance in terms of capacity enterprise as well. And I mean, there's a lot of dynamics. The other thing just to add is that we continue to make progress in terms of our integration synergy goals. So that continues to provide
componenttext: Yes. And also, the strong performance in terms of capacity enterprise as well. And I mean, there's a lot of dynamics. The other thing just to add is that we continue to make progress in terms of our integration synergy goals. So that continues to provide some headwind -- or not headwind. That's a tailwind for us in terms of our margin performance. So it was really kind of -- to oversimplify it, it was kind of a little bit of everything kind of across the board.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right, and -- yes, just to finish that thought, we would expect those same drivers to carry forward into the second fiscal quarter, and that's driving the expansion of gross margin.
componenttext: Right, and -- yes, just to finish that thought, we would expect those same drivers to carry forward into the second fiscal quarter, and that's driving the expansion of gross margin.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And as a follow-up, I understand that you're only including about 45 days of that Samsung contribution, which makes sense. If or when you get a resolution with Samsung, would they back pay your payments from November 15 onwards? Or any -- your sense [indi
componenttext: And as a follow-up, I understand that you're only including about 45 days of that Samsung contribution, which makes sense. If or when you get a resolution with Samsung, would they back pay your payments from November 15 onwards? Or any -- your sense [indiscernible] ?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: We would certainly hope so, yes. Because the agreement expired on August 14, so when we put a new agreement in place, we would expect it to be retroactive to that date.
componenttext: We would certainly hope so, yes. Because the agreement expired on August 14, so when we put a new agreement in place, we would expect it to be retroactive to that date.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of James Kisner with Jefferies.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of James Kisner with Jefferies.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: So when you said nearline demand was up 50% year-over-year in exabyte shipped, I was wondering if you could just comment a little bit on how that translates to revenue change year-over-year and I guess, relatedly the change in price per bit year-over-year
componenttext: So when you said nearline demand was up 50% year-over-year in exabyte shipped, I was wondering if you could just comment a little bit on how that translates to revenue change year-over-year and I guess, relatedly the change in price per bit year-over-year. And I guess, relatedly, have you seen more rational competitive environment for nearline? And what has happened to your share in nearline quarter-on-quarter?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: So from a translation to revenue standpoint, it's about half that in terms of the increase in revenue.
componenttext: So from a translation to revenue standpoint, it's about half that in terms of the increase in revenue.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. In terms of market dynamics, I think -- we think it's fairly balanced and as we expected. And I think relative to bit, total bit participation, we think we've improved our position sequentially, and we see a trend of that going forward really relativ
componenttext: Yes. In terms of market dynamics, I think -- we think it's fairly balanced and as we expected. And I think relative to bit, total bit participation, we think we've improved our position sequentially, and we see a trend of that going forward really relative to our increasing sales of our 10-terabyte offering.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Steven Fox with Cross Research.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Steven Fox with Cross Research.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just getting back to your revenue guidance for a second. I was wondering if there's any other puts and takes you can talk to in terms of how you get to the flat either by the 3 business segments you've established or maybe even hopefully by some product c
componenttext: Just getting back to your revenue guidance for a second. I was wondering if there's any other puts and takes you can talk to in terms of how you get to the flat either by the 3 business segments you've established or maybe even hopefully by some product categories as well. And then I had a enterprise follow-up question.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So let me talk about our end markets. For data center devices, you can think about that whole category being roughly flat. When it comes to client devices, I think within that, while the whole category again will be roughly flat, you'll have some pu
componenttext: Sure. So let me talk about our end markets. For data center devices, you can think about that whole category being roughly flat. When it comes to client devices, I think within that, while the whole category again will be roughly flat, you'll have some puts and takes. You'll see continued strength in client SSD, but we'll see gaming and to some extent, notebook HDDs sort of come off that seasonal peak. And then we'll see a little strength in desktop. When it comes to our client solutions, we actually see a strength across both our HDD and flash-based products. So I think, on balance, it's sort of flat to slightly up for each of the 3 categories.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: The largest single variable there is the seasonality of the gaming marketplace, so that peaks, as Mark said, in calendar Q3. So that's the largest single sort of variable within.
componenttext: The largest single variable there is the seasonality of the gaming marketplace, so that peaks, as Mark said, in calendar Q3. So that's the largest single sort of variable within.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. That's helpful. And then just as a follow-up, as you mentioned, you have a unique view into enterprise storage now. I was wondering if you could just compare capacity, average capacity trends between HDDs and SSDs into some of the cloud data center
componenttext: Great. That's helpful. And then just as a follow-up, as you mentioned, you have a unique view into enterprise storage now. I was wondering if you could just compare capacity, average capacity trends between HDDs and SSDs into some of the cloud data centers that you're -- you have projects in, how the growth rates compare and contrast.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. On a growth rate basis, the capacity growth rate for flash exceeds that of disk. And so that trend continues. That's been ongoing for some time, and that's really specifically related to hyperscale deployment.
componenttext: Yes. On a growth rate basis, the capacity growth rate for flash exceeds that of disk. And so that trend continues. That's been ongoing for some time, and that's really specifically related to hyperscale deployment.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Rich Kugele with Needham & Company.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Rich Kugele with Needham & Company.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just one question for me, tagging onto that last question, so Micron, for example, has been touting its 15-terabyte drive. And I'm just interested in -- maybe best for Mike, how do you see the next few years playing out on the highest capacity points betw
componenttext: Just one question for me, tagging onto that last question, so Micron, for example, has been touting its 15-terabyte drive. And I'm just interested in -- maybe best for Mike, how do you see the next few years playing out on the highest capacity points between hard drives and SSDs. How do you position these 2? And does WD get to a point where it's just indifferent to whatever people select for cloud, hyperscale environments?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So I think, Rich, it still begins with the workload and then the cost per bit that optimally supports that workload. So going forward, we don't see sort of a convergence to an all-flash world anytime soon, frankly, anytime on our planning horizon. So
componenttext: Yes. So I think, Rich, it still begins with the workload and then the cost per bit that optimally supports that workload. So going forward, we don't see sort of a convergence to an all-flash world anytime soon, frankly, anytime on our planning horizon. So what we do see is continued growth of capacity enterprise that we articulated, and that's going to be long into the future although flash, flash revenue and flash bps on a proportionate basis is growing faster. So from that standpoint, that's the trend we would point you to. And they have very different purposes in the hierarchy. So we continue to obviously work closely with those that are innovating around data center architectures, and we intend to sort of deploy our technology and our products in an optimal way to those trends.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: How much of a price differential is there today between the SSD version and a comparable capacity hard drive?
componenttext: How much of a price differential is there today between the SSD version and a comparable capacity hard drive?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: It varies depending on sort of performance requirements, et cetera, but it would run between 5 and 10x.
componenttext: It varies depending on sort of performance requirements, et cetera, but it would run between 5 and 10x.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Mark Moskowitz with Barclays.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Mark Moskowitz with Barclays.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I apologize if the questions have been asked. I've been jumping between a couple of calls. The first question is can you talk a little more about next year: If demand improvements in both flash and disk drives continue from an end market perspective, can
componenttext: I apologize if the questions have been asked. I've been jumping between a couple of calls. The first question is can you talk a little more about next year: If demand improvements in both flash and disk drives continue from an end market perspective, can we see any capacity perhaps recently driving a shortage or a constraint issue next year from one or both segments? And the other question is around the exclusion of stock options. Can you talk a little more about the philosophy there just given that we all are kind of -- were aware of SanDisk and the overhang there previously? Why the change now? What's kind of the impetus? That would be great.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Let me talk about sort of the supply-demand environment. We said publicly and we'll reiterate here that we see constrained supply in the NAND side of our business through calendar year 2017. And that's primarily driven by 2 things: end market demand
componenttext: Okay. Let me talk about sort of the supply-demand environment. We said publicly and we'll reiterate here that we see constrained supply in the NAND side of our business through calendar year 2017. And that's primarily driven by 2 things: end market demand for that class of technology and the rate and pace of the industry's conversion to 3D NAND. Relative to the hard drive market, I think, at this point, we would see that as sort of a normal or balanced environment.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then, Mark, with respect to the decision to exclude stock-based compensation expense from our non-GAAP results, we really had 2 primary drivers. One was just the way we run the business. And our stock-based compensation expense actually has some eleme
componenttext: And then, Mark, with respect to the decision to exclude stock-based compensation expense from our non-GAAP results, we really had 2 primary drivers. One was just the way we run the business. And our stock-based compensation expense actually has some elements of it that are either short term in nature or are variable, and as a result, it injects some variability that undermines our ability to demonstrate or track the improvements we're making from a synergy realization standpoint. So that's kind of the first driver. The second driver is that we are more and more focused on our cash flow generation and looking at our results from a cash standpoint, particularly given our balance sheet, and by excluding the stock-based compensation, we are better able to highlight and track the cash flow impacts of our operating decision.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Now one thing, Mark, that I will add to that -- this is Steve -- is that we fully recognize the fact that there is a impact in the form of dilution from stock-based compensation, and we remain not only aware of that but sensitive to that. And if you look
componenttext: Now one thing, Mark, that I will add to that -- this is Steve -- is that we fully recognize the fact that there is a impact in the form of dilution from stock-based compensation, and we remain not only aware of that but sensitive to that. And if you look at our proxy statement in terms of compensation philosophies and that sort of thing, there's no change in that regard in terms of what we're doing. It's more a matter of excluding those figures to provide more meaningful analytical information, if you want to call it that, to the financial community. But I don't want people to think that we don't recognize the fact that there is a dilution component as it relates to our existing shareholders.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Mark, we -- I think, as you know, we -- part of the calculus was looking at the comparable peers and what they do to try to provide an easier basis for comparison. So...
componenttext: And Mark, we -- I think, as you know, we -- part of the calculus was looking at the comparable peers and what they do to try to provide an easier basis for comparison. So...

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Karl Ackerman with Cowen and Company.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Karl Ackerman with Cowen and Company.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I know it's difficult to guide NAND gross margins since ASPs are beyond your control. But do you think your cost improvement will be above or below your long-term expectations of 20% in 2016 as you ramp 3D? And maybe what's your expectation in 2017, calen
componenttext: I know it's difficult to guide NAND gross margins since ASPs are beyond your control. But do you think your cost improvement will be above or below your long-term expectations of 20% in 2016 as you ramp 3D? And maybe what's your expectation in 2017, calendar 2017, as 3D becomes a larger part of your mix? And I had a follow-up, please.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So we've talked about sort of the cost reduction domain of kind of 3 generations -- or 3 periods in the NAND industry. Very early on, it was running at around a 50% annualized rate. The next period, it was running at about a 30% rate. Frankly, that'
componenttext: Okay. So we've talked about sort of the cost reduction domain of kind of 3 generations -- or 3 periods in the NAND industry. Very early on, it was running at around a 50% annualized rate. The next period, it was running at about a 30% rate. Frankly, that's now ending as we come to the conclusion of planar NAND. As we move fully as an industry into 3D, once we're through the transition, we expect around a 20% per year cost-reduction capability. So that's the way we would guide you to think about that. Obviously, there are some perturbations as we transition from 2D to 3D, but that's the way to think about it from a long-term modeling perspective.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. I can appreciate that. And then in the context of your bit growth outlook for calendar 2017 that you just gave and also your past comments that 3D NAND will be 40% of your overall bit output by the end of next calendar year, should we expect the m
componenttext: Got it. I can appreciate that. And then in the context of your bit growth outlook for calendar 2017 that you just gave and also your past comments that 3D NAND will be 40% of your overall bit output by the end of next calendar year, should we expect the majority of your 3D outlook to be 64 layer? Or will it be more weighted toward a 48 layer?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: It'll be 64 layer. And I think we have a -- what's the right number for exit rate in 2017?
componenttext: It'll be 64 layer. And I think we have a -- what's the right number for exit rate in 2017?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's around 40 minutes, wafers out.
componenttext: It's around 40 minutes, wafers out.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Oh, okay. So not bit output. It's just wafers out. Okay so the 40% is wafers out.
componenttext: Oh, okay. So not bit output. It's just wafers out. Okay so the 40% is wafers out.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Correct. And the other comment I'll make just to clarify, 48 layer, we've talked about, is really a learning node for us. So to just reiterate what Steve said, the volume, as we exit next calendar year, will be predominantly the 64 layer.
componenttext: Correct. And the other comment I'll make just to clarify, 48 layer, we've talked about, is really a learning node for us. So to just reiterate what Steve said, the volume, as we exit next calendar year, will be predominantly the 64 layer.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Ananda Baruah with Brean Capital.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Ananda Baruah with Brean Capital.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: One and then a quick follow-up. Steve, would love your -- I guess, your context on given now on the hard drive side of things, the capacity in the industry is pretty well rationalized and I guess has the potential, based on cloud growth going into next ye
componenttext: One and then a quick follow-up. Steve, would love your -- I guess, your context on given now on the hard drive side of things, the capacity in the industry is pretty well rationalized and I guess has the potential, based on cloud growth going into next year, to maybe be -- I mean, it sounds fantastic but close to 100% by midyear. Does -- what implications, if any, does that then have on, I guess, the context, the tenor of your relationships with customers, your conversations with customers, business practices with customers? In any regard, would love to get your sense there. And then I have a quick follow-up on a different topic.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, yes. Ananda, I mean, Mark -- Mike can help you with this as well. But I think that one of the things that has really happened over a period of time, because as the hyperscale guys grow and they get bigger and as they need to add capacity and [indisc
componenttext: Well, yes. Ananda, I mean, Mark -- Mike can help you with this as well. But I think that one of the things that has really happened over a period of time, because as the hyperscale guys grow and they get bigger and as they need to add capacity and [indiscernible] -- their growth is accelerating, right? And so you just get into, call it, the law of large numbers. We have to do a much better job working with the hyperscale guys on longer-term capacity planning. And so we believe we've done a good job on that because we don't -- they don't want to ask us for product and us not have it. And then clearly, we don't want to gap out on them. And so it's driven, in effect, a much more close-knit planning process, longer-term planning process, which the good side of that is that it allows for a little bit more predictability in terms of what's going on in that side of the business because there was a time -- well, it can still happen. But there's been conversations about the lumpiness of the business, and that can still occur. But because of the dynamics that we're seeing, it's -- we're actually getting into a little bit more longer-term planning and a little bit more predictability in terms of what's happening from a demand perspective. Mike can kind of add to that.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. And I'll just sort of reiterate some of the reasons this is. So we've talked about this long-term growth rate of 35%. We've been, as an industry, achieving that with a number of efficiency factors flowing through. We've highlighted in the past both t
componenttext: Yes. And I'll just sort of reiterate some of the reasons this is. So we've talked about this long-term growth rate of 35%. We've been, as an industry, achieving that with a number of efficiency factors flowing through. We've highlighted in the past both technological as well as operational. So technologically, things like erasure coding are widely deployed now in those -- in that infrastructure. So the sort of efficiency gains technologically, although we expect some in the future, the largest magnitude of that have sort of run its course. The other one is operational efficiency, and that underpins what Steve said. They're maturing as operational units. Their ability to sort of do things like manage inventory and repurpose and reutilize their feet, that -- those processes are maturing. So really, what we now see and perhaps one of the reasons we're seeing a bias up on the exabyte growth rate is we're kind of working through those things, and we're starting to approach a more natural storage deploy requirement. So that's something we'll continue to monitor and see how that trends. At this point, we'll kind of stick with 35%, but as I've said, I think our bias would be up from there going forward.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Steve and Mike, with sort of working more closely with those folks, would that include anything in the context of contractual added alterations? I mean, could a long-term -- I'm just coming off the top of my head -- longer-term contracts play into it
componenttext: And Steve and Mike, with sort of working more closely with those folks, would that include anything in the context of contractual added alterations? I mean, could a long-term -- I'm just coming off the top of my head -- longer-term contracts play into it in any context, maybe capital sharing play into it in any context, anything with financial implications longer term?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I'll say this. I think the general view of us now as we've put together this broader set of assets is we're more relevant, we're more strategically important, and our engagement is changing with the broader marketplace. So things along those lines a
componenttext: Well, I'll say this. I think the general view of us now as we've put together this broader set of assets is we're more relevant, we're more strategically important, and our engagement is changing with the broader marketplace. So things along those lines and other strategic things are all sort of more possible then.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you. So I want to thank you all for joining us today. We look forward to seeing many of you at our Investor Day on December 6. Have a good day.
componenttext: Thank you. So I want to thank you all for joining us today. We look forward to seeing many of you at our Investor Day on December 6. Have a good day.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ladies and gentlemen, this does conclude the program, and you may all disconnect. Everyone, have a great day.
componenttext: Ladies and gentlemen, this does conclude the program, and you may all disconnect. Everyone, have a great day.
